CHAPTER 1
FIRE INSURANCE COMPANIES
SECTION:
3-1-1: Tax Imposed
3-1-2: Report Premiums
3-1-3: Payment Of Tax
3-1-4: Nonpayment Of Tax
3-1-5: Fire Department Fund
3-1-1: TAX IMPOSED:
All corporations, companies and associations not incorporated under the laws of
this State, and which are engaged in the City in affecting or soliciting fire
insurance shall pay to the Treasurer of the City, annually upon July 15, a sum
equal to two percent (2%) of the gross receipts of premiums received by such
corporation, company or association or their agency or agents for business
affected or transacted for fire insurance within the City, for the year ending
with July 1. The percent above named shall be a tax or license fee upon all
such corporations, companies or associations transacting said business within
the City. (Ord. 37, 3-9-1896)
3-1-2: REPORT PREMIUMS:
Every person acting as agent or otherwise for or on behalf of any such
corporation, company or association shall, on or before July 15 in each and
every year, render to the City Clerk a full, true and just account verified by
oath of all premiums which, during the year ending on July 1, shall have been
received by him or any other person for him in behalf of any such corporation,
company or association, and shall fully and specifically set out in said report
the amount or amounts received as premium for fire insurance. (Ord. 37, 3-9-
1896)
3-1-3: PAYMENT OF TAX:
The agent or agents aforesaid shall also at the time of the making of the above
mentioned report, pay to the Treasurer of the City the said sum of two percent
(2%) upon the gross receipts of such corporation, company or association
obtained as premiums for affecting fire insurance in the City, as is specified
in section
3-1-2 of this chapter. (Ord. 37, 3-9-1896)
3-1-4: NONPAYMENT OF TAX:
If such account be not rendered on or before the day herein designated for the
purpose, or if the above mentioned rates for the said tax or license fee shall
remain unpaid after that day, it shall be unlawful for any such corporation,
company or association to transact any business of fire insurance in the City
until the requirements hereof have been fully complied with. Nevertheless, this
provision shall in no way affect the validity of any risk that may be taken in
violation hereof between such corporation, company or association, and the
person so insured.
If any such corporation, company or association fails to render the account or
report herein designated by the day required by this chapter, or if the above
mentioned rates as a tax or license fee shall remain unpaid after the day
designated, being July 15, every such corporation, company or association shall
forfeit and pay to the City the sum of two hundred dollars ($200.00) upon
conviction for each and every offense, and in addition to said penalty the City
shall recover in an action in its name for its use against such corporation,
company or association so failing to make such report, or pay such license fee
or tax, the full amount of the said license fee, which would be due under the
provisions hereof. (Ord. 37, 3-9-1896)
3-1-5: FIRE DEPARTMENT FUND:
Any and all sums so received under the provisions hereof shall form and
constitute a fund to be kept separate by the Treasurer of the City for the
maintenance, use and benefit of the Fire Department of the City. (Ord. 37, 3-9-
1896)
CHAPTER 2
LIQUOR REGULATIONS
SECTION:
3-2-1: Definitions
3-2-2: Acceptance Of Regulations
3-2-3: License Required
3-2-4: Additional Licenses Required
3-2-5: Application; Procedure; Contents
3-2-6: Persons Eligible For License
3-2-7: Classification Of Licenses And Fees
3-2-8: Selling Without License
3-2-9: Restriction On Number, Classification
3-2-10: License Periods
3-2-11: Disposition Of Fees
3-2-12: Records Of Licenses
3-2-13: Transferability Of Licenses
3-2-14: Sanitary Requirements
3-2-15: Hours, Days Of Sale
3-2-16: Visibility Of Interior
3-2-17: Enforcement Of Visibility, Lighting Requirements
3-2-18: Sales To Minors, Certain Persons
3-2-19: Sale, Delivery In City Buildings
3-2-20: Employing Minors
3-2-21: Identification, Proof Of Age
3-2-22: Political Campaign Contributions
3-2-23: Owner Responsible
3-2-24: Liability Of Licensee
3-2-25: Public View, Public Place
3-2-26: Sign Warning Required
3-2-27: Revocation; Power Of Liquor Commissioner
3-2-28: Penalties
3-2-29: Compensation Of Liquor Commissioner
3-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
All words and phrases used in this chapter which are defined in 235 Illinois
Compiled Statutes, as amended, shall have the meanings according to such words
and phrases in said statute. (Ord. 74-12, 12-16-1974)
3-2-2: ACCEPTANCE OF REGULATIONS:
Any person who accepts any alcoholic liquor license issued under this chapter
hereby accepts and agrees to comply with all of the terms and conditions of
this chapter and all other applicable provisions of this Code. (Ord. 74-12, 12-
16-1974)
3-2-3: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale at retail within the City any
alcoholic liquor without first having obtained a retail dealer's license for
each location, place or premises where alcoholic liquor is sold or offered for
sale. (Ord. 74-12, 12-16-1974)
3-2-4: ADDITIONAL LICENSES REQUIRED:
The issuance of any license under this chapter shall not relieve the holder
thereof from acquiring other licenses and paying any fees that may be required
by this City for the sale or distribution of products or the performance of any
other service; provided, however, holders of liquor licenses may without
further licenses or fees serve soft drinks incident to their principal purpose.
(Ord. 74-12, 12-16-1974)
3-2-5: APPLICATION; PROCEDURE; CONTENTS:
An application for a City retailer's license for the sale of alcoholic liquor
shall be made in writing to the City Clerk who shall forward the application to
the Mayor, as the Local Liquor Control Commissioner, for such action as the
Mayor may see fit to take pursuant to the law of this State and the provisions
of this Code. The application must be signed by the applicant, if an
individual, or by a duly authorized agent thereof, if a club or corporation,
verified by oath or affidavit, and should contain the following information and
statements:
   (A)   The name, age and address of the applicant in case of an individual;
in the case of a copartnership, the persons entitled to share in the profits
thereof; and in case of a corporation for profit or a club, the date of
incorporation, the objects for which it was organized, the names and addresses
of the officers and directors, and if a majority in interest of the stock of
such corporation is owned by one person or his nominee, the name and address of
such person, and his nominee, if any.
   (B)   The citizenship of the applicant, his place of birth and if a
naturalized citizen, the time and place of his naturalization.
   (C)   The character of business of the applicant; and in case of a
corporation, the object for which it was formed.
   (D)   The length of time said applicant has been in business of that
character, or in the case of a corporation, the date on which its charter was
issued.
   (E)   The amount of goods, wares and merchandise on hand at the time
application was made.
   (F)   The location and description of the premises or place of business
which is to be operated under such license.
   (G)   A statement whether the applicant has made a similar application, for
a similar other license on premises anywhere including the premises described
in this application and the disposition of such application.
   (H)   The statement that applicant has never been convicted of a felony and
is not disqualified to receive a license by reason of any matter or thing
contained in this chapter, laws of this State or the provisions of this Code.
   (I)   Where a previous license by any state or subdivision thereof, by the
Federal government, has been revoked, and the reason therefor.
   (J)   A statement that the applicant will not violate any of the laws of the
State of Illinois or the United States, or any provision of this chapter or
other provisions of this Code in the conduct of his place of business. (Ord.
74-12, 12-16-1974)
3-2-6: PERSONS ELIGIBLE FOR LICENSE:
No license required by this chapter shall be issued to:
   (A)   Any person or persons who have not reached the age of twenty one (21).
   (B)   A person who is not of good character and reputation in the community
in which he resides.
   (C)   A person who is not a citizen of the United States.
   (D)   A person who has been convicted of a felony under any Federal or State
law.
   (E)   A person who has been convicted of being the keeper or keeping a house
of ill-fame.
   (F)   A person who has been convicted of pandering or other crime or
misdemeanor opposed to decency and morality.
   (G)   A person who at the time of application for renewal of any license
issued hereunder would not be eligible for such license upon first application.
   (H)   A person whose license issued under this chapter has been revoked for
cause.
   (I)   A copartnership unless all members of such copartnership shall be
qualified to obtain a license.
   (J)   A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof or any
stockholder owning in the aggregate of more than five percent (5%) of the stock
of such corporation would not be eligible to receive a license hereunder for
any reason other than citizenship or residence within the City.
   (K)   A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent
unless such manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required by the
licensee.
   (L)   A person who has been convicted of a violation of any Federal or State
law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor,
subsequent to the effective date hereof and preceding provisions regulating the
retail sale of alcoholic liquors in the City or shall have forfeited his bond
to appear in court to answer charges for any such violation.
   (M)   Any law-enforcing public official, any Mayor of the City, any Alderman
of the City; and no such official shall be interested either directly or
indirectly in the manufacture, sale or distribution of alcoholic liquor in the
City.
   (N)   Any person, association or corporation not eligible for a State retail
liquor dealer's license.
   (O)   No such license shall be issued to a person who is not a resident of
the City.
   (P)   No such license shall be issued to any person who has ever been
committed to any City, County, State, Federal or probate institution for the
mentally incompetent.
   (Q)   A person, firm or corporation which does not own the premises for
which a license is sought, or does not have a lease thereon for the full period
for which the license is to be issued. (Ord. 74-12, 12-16-1974)
3-2-7: CLASSIFICATION OF LICENSES AND FEES:
There are hereby created the following classifications of licenses for the
retail sale of alcoholic liquor:
   (A)   Class A License:
      1.   Class A licenses which authorize retail sale on the premises of
alcoholic liquor for the consumption on the premises as well as other retail
sales of liquor. The annual fee for such license shall be one thousand dollars
($1,000.00).
      2.   An additional fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be
required of all holders of Class A licenses to engage in the sale of alcoholic
liquors on Sunday during the hours of one o'clock (1:00) P.M. to twelve o'clock
(12:00) midnight.
   (B)   Class B Licenses:
      1.   Class B licenses which authorize retail sale of alcoholic liquor but
not for the consumption on the premises where sold. The annual fee for such
license shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 74-12, 12-16-1974)
      2.   An additional fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) shall be
required of all holders of Class B licenses to engage in the sale of alcoholic
liquors on Sunday during the hours of six o'clock (6:00) A.M. to twelve o'clock
(12:00) midnight. (Ord. 2015-15, 4-26-2016)
   (C)   Class C Licenses:
      1.   Class C licenses authorize the retail sale by clubs to members
thereof on the premises specified of all alcoholic liquors. The annual fee for
such licenses shall be three hundred dollars ($300.00).
      2.   An additional fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) shall be
required of all holders of Class C licenses to engage in the sale of alcoholic
liquors on Sunday during the hours of one o'clock (1:00) P.M. to twelve o'clock
(12:00) midnight. (Ord. 74-12, 12-16-1974)
   (D)   Class D Licenses:
      1.   Class D licenses authorize the retail sale on the premises and for
the consumption on the premises of beer and wine only. The annual fee for such
license shall be eight hundred dollars ($800.00).
      2.   An additional fee of four hundred dollars ($400.00) shall be
required of all holders of Class D licenses to engage in the sale of beer and
wine on Sunday during the hours of one o'clock (1:00) P.M. to twelve o'clock
(12:00) midnight. (Ord. 80-16, 11-12-1980)
   (E)   Class SD Licenses: Class SD licenses (single day licenses) shall
authorize the retail sale for a single day of alcoholic beverages in accordance
with the terms and conditions provided for in such license. Class SD licenses
shall be granted only upon the approval of the City Council and the Liquor
Commissioner. The fee for such license shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). (Ord.
88-12, 2-28-1989)
3-2-8: SELLING WITHOUT LICENSE:
The retail delivery or sale of alcoholic liquor whether for cash or its
equivalent or as the result of the payment of any admission fee to the premises
or any other indirect method of payment therefor other than pursuant to Class
A, Class B, Class C, Class D and Class SD license as hereinbefore specified, is
hereby prohibited. (Ord. 88-12, 2-28-1989)
3-2-9: RESTRICTION ON NUMBER, CLASSIFICATION:
The total number and classification of liquor licenses to be issued in the City
shall be, unless otherwise changed by action of the City Council, and are
hereby set at:
   (A)   Eight (8) Class A licenses.
   (B)   Five (5) Class B licenses.
   (C)   Three (3) Class C licenses.
   (D)   Three (3) Class D licenses.
If any licensee holding a liquor license under the provisions of this chapter
fails to renew his license, as by law provided, or the same is surrendered,
cancelled, revoked or otherwise terminated, such license of any class shall not
be restored if there are at least four (4) Class A licenses, five (5) Class B
licenses, three (3) Class C licenses or three (3) Class D licenses in full
force and effect. (Ord. 74-12, 12-16-1974; amd. Ord. 80-16, 11-12-1980; Ord.
85-9, 1-14-1986; Ord. 91-2, 8-13-1991; Ord. 93-2, 5-11-1993; Ord. 2019-5, 10-8-
2019)
3-2-10: LICENSE PERIODS:
Class A licenses, Class B licenses, Class C licenses and Class D licenses shall
terminate on April 30 next following their issuance. (Ord. 80-16, 11-12-1980)
3-2-11: DISPOSITION OF FEES:
All fees required by this chapter shall be paid to the City Clerk at the time
an application is made and shall forthwith be turned over to the Treasurer. In
the event the license applied for is denied the fee shall be returned to the
applicant. If the license is granted, then the fee shall be deposited in the
General Corporate Fund or in such other fund as shall have been designated by
the City Council, by proper action. The fee to be paid shall be reduced in
proportion to the full calendar months which have expired in the year prior to
the issuance of the license. (Ord. 74-12, 12-16-1974)
3-2-12: RECORDS OF LICENSES:
The Clerk shall keep or cause to be kept a complete record of all licenses
issued under this chapter and shall furnish the Mayor, Treasurer and Chief of
Police each with a copy thereof; upon the issuance of any license or the
revocation of any old license, the Mayor shall give written notice of such
action to each of these officers within forty eight (48) hours of such action.
(Ord. 74-12, 12-16-1974)
3-2-13: TRANSFERABILITY OF LICENSES:
A license shall be purely a personal privilege, good for only the period
specified therefor in section
3-2-10 of this chapter unless sooner revoked as in this chapter provided, and
shall not constitute property nor shall it be subject to attachment,
garnishment or execution, nor shall it be alienable or transferable,
voluntarily or involuntarily or subject to be encumbered or hypothecated. Such
license shall not descend by the laws of the State or intestate devolution, but
it shall cease upon the death of the licensee provided that executors or
administrators of the estate of the deceased licensee, and the trustee of any
insolvent or bankrupt licensees when such estate consists in part of alcoholic
liquor, may continue the business of the sale or manufacture of alcoholic
liquor under order of the appropriate court, and may exercise the privilege of
the deceased or insolvent or bankrupt until the expiration of such license, but
not longer than six (6) months after the death, bankruptcy or insolvency of
such licensee. (Ord. 74-12, 12-16-1974)
3-2-14: SANITARY REQUIREMENTS:
Every person who is licensed hereunder who shall sell any alcoholic liquor for
consumption on the premises of such licensee shall keep and maintain the
adequate sanitary washing facilities for the cleaning of glasses and service
utensils, shall provide adequate toilet facilities for both male and female,
and shall otherwise comply with all health and sanitary requirements of the
provisions of this Code applicable to licensed business, if any. All employees
shall be clean in person and in clothing, and no person afflicted with any
contagious disease in communicable form shall be employed in or about the
serving of liquor or in the washing of glasses or other utensils. (Ord. 74-12,
12-16-1974)
3-2-15: HOURS, DAYS OF SALE:
   (A)   It shall be lawful to sell or offer for sale at retail alcoholic
liquors under Class A, B, C and D licenses during the following hours:
      1.   On Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday between the hours of six
o'clock (6:00) A.M. and twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight.
      2.   On Friday between the hours of six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and one
o'clock (1:00) A.M. the following day.
      3.   On Saturday between the hours of six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and one
o'clock (1:00) A.M. the next day. (Ord. 80-16, 11-12-1980)
      4.   For Classes A, C and D, on Sunday between the hours of one o'clock
(1:00) P.M. and twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight. (Ord. 80-16, 11-12-1980; amd.
Ord. 2015-15, 4-26-2016)
For Class B, on Sunday between the hours of six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and twelve
o'clock (12:00) midnight. (Ord. 2015-15, 4-26-2016)
   (B)   On New Year's Eve alcoholic liquors may be sold at retail until two
o'clock (2:00) A.M. the following morning. (Ord. 74-12, 12-16-1974)
   (C)   There shall be no consumption of alcoholic liquors on any portion of
the licensed premises after thirty (30) minutes from the time of closing as
hereinabove stated. (Ord. 77-18, 3-14-1978)
3-2-16: VISIBILITY OF INTERIOR:
In premises upon which the sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption upon the
premises is licensed (other than as a restaurant, hotel or club), no screen,
blind, curtain, partition, article or thing shall be permitted in the windows
or upon the doors of such licensed premises nor inside such premises which
shall prevent a clear view into the interior of such licensed premises from the
street, road or sidewalk at all times, and no booths, screen, partition or
other obstruction nor any arrangement of light or lighting shall be permitted
in or about the interior of such premises which shall prevent a full view of
the entire interior of such premises from the street, road or sidewalk, and
said premises must be so located that there shall be full view of the entire
interior of such premises from the street, road or sidewalk. All rooms where
liquor is sold for consumption upon the premises shall be continuously lighted
during business hours by natural light or official white light so that all
parts of the interior of the premises shall be clearly visible. In case the
view into any such licensed premises required by the foregoing provision shall
be wilfully suffered to be obscured or in any manner obstructed, then such
license shall be subject to revocation or suspension in the manner herein
provided. (Ord. 74-12, 12-16-1974; amd. 1979 Code)
3-2-17: ENFORCEMENT OF VISIBILITY, LIGHTING REQUIREMENTS:
In order to enforce the provisions of the foregoing section of this chapter the
Mayor as Liquor Commissioner shall have the right to require the filing with
him of plans, drawings and photographs showing the clearness of view and
lighting as specified in the above section. (Ord. 74-12, 12-16-1974; amd. 1979
Code)
3-2-18: SALES TO MINORS, CERTAIN PERSONS:
   (A)   No licensee nor any officer, associate, member or representative,
agent or employee of such licensee shall sell, give or deliver alcoholic liquor
to any person under the age of twenty one (21) years, or to any intoxicated
person or to any person known by him to be a habitual drunkard, spendthrift,
insane, mentally ill, mentally deficient or in need of mental treatment. No
person, after purchasing or otherwise obtaining alcoholic liquor, shall sell,
give or deliver such alcoholic liquor to any person under the age of twenty one
(21) years, except in the performance of a religious ceremony or service.
   (B)   Any person of legal age who shall purchase alcoholic liquor for the
purpose of giving or delivering any of said alcoholic liquor to any minor or
any person not entitled to the same because of age or otherwise as hereinabove
provided, within the City, except the parent or legal guardian of such person
shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
   (C)   Any person to whom the sale, gift or delivery of alcoholic liquor is
prohibited because of age shall not purchase or accept a gift of alcoholic
liquor. (Ord. 74-12, 12-16-1974; amd. 1979 Code)
3-2-19: SALE, DELIVERY IN CITY BUILDINGS:
No alcoholic liquor shall be sold or delivered in any building belonging to the
City. (Ord. 74-12, 12-16-1974; amd. 1979 Code)
3-2-20: EMPLOYING MINORS:
   (A)   It is unlawful to permit any person under the age of nineteen (19)
years to draw, pour or mix any alcoholic liquor as an employee of any retail
licensee; in the sale, distribution, packaging, delivery of alcoholic liquors,
no liquor licensee licensed by the City may employ, with or without
compensation, or in any way directly or indirectly use the services of a person
under the age of nineteen (19) years.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of nineteen (19)
years unless accompanied by a parent or other authorized legal guardian to be
in or on any premises where the principal business includes the sale of
alcoholic liquors other than wine and beer. (Ord. 74-12, 12-16-1974; amd. 1979
Code)
3-2-21: IDENTIFICATION, PROOF OF AGE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to transfer, alter or deface an
identification card, use the identification card of another, carry or use a
false or forged identification card or to obtain an identification card by
means of false information.
If a licensee or his agents or employees believe or have reason to believe that
the sale or delivery of alcoholic liquor is prohibited because of the non-age
of the prospective recipient, he shall, before making such sale or delivery
demand a representation of some form of positive identification, containing
proof of age, issued by a public officer in the performance of his official
duties. (Ord. 74-12, 12-16-1974; amd. 1979 Code)
3-2-22: POLITICAL CAMPAIGN CONTRIBUTIONS:
It is unlawful for any licensee, where more than five percent (5%) of the
licensee's gross income is derived from the sale of alcoholic liquor, or any
officer, associate, representative, agent or employee of such licensee to
become liable for, pay or make any contributions directly or indirectly towards
the campaign funds or expenses of any political party, or candidate for public
office or for nomination of any candidate for public office within the City.
(Ord. 74-12, 12-16-1974; amd. 1979 Code)
3-2-23: OWNER RESPONSIBLE:
If the owner of the licensed premises or any person from whom the licensee
derives the right of possession of such premises, or the agent of such owner or
person shall knowingly permit the licensee to use his licensed premises in
violation of the terms of this chapter, said owner, agent or other person shall
be deemed guilty of a violation of this chapter to the same extent as said
licensee and shall be subject to same punishment. (Ord. 74-12, 12-16-1974; amd.
1979 Code)
3-2-24: LIABILITY OF LICENSEE:
Every act or admission of whatsoever nature constituting a violation of any of
the provisions of this chapter by any officer, director, manager or other agent
or employee of any licensee shall be deemed and held to be the act of such
employer or licensee, and said employer or licensee shall be punishable in the
same manner as if said act or admission had been done by him personally. (Ord.
74-12, 12-16-1974; amd. 1979 Code)
3-2-25: PUBLIC VIEW, PUBLIC PLACE:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to whom the sale, gift or delivery
of alcoholic liquor is prohibited because of age, and who has consumed
alcoholic liquor to be in public view or in a public place in the City.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to drink, transport, carry,
possess or have alcoholic liquor except in the original package and with the
seal unbroken on any public sidewalk, street, alley or other public place in
the City. (Ord. 79-2, 6-12-1979)
3-2-26: SIGN WARNING REQUIRED:
Every holder of a Class A, Class B, Class C, Class D and Class SD license in
the City where alcoholic liquor is sold shall display at all times in a
prominent place a printed card which shall be issued by the City Clerk and
shall read substantially as follows:
WARNING
You are subject to a fine up to $500.00 under the provisions of the City Code
of Carthage, Hancock County, Illinois, if you purchase or accept alcoholic
liquor, beer or wine, otherwise prohibited because of your age, or misrepresent
your age for the purpose of purchasing or obtaining alcoholic liquor, beer or
wine.
(Ord. 88-12, 2-28-1989)
3-2-27: REVOCATION; POWER OF LIQUOR COMMISSIONER:
The Mayor, as Liquor Commissioner of the City, shall have the power to suspend
or revoke any liquor license hereunder for violation of any section of this
chapter, as specified in 235 Illinois Compiled Statutes, and all other powers
granted to him in the aforesaid chapter of the Illinois Compiled Statutes,
subject to the restriction and procedures contained therein. (Ord. 74-12, 12-
16-1974)
3-2-28: PENALTIES:
Any person violating any provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less
than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00)
for a first offense and for each offense thereafter not less than one hundred
dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 74-12,
12-16-1974; amd. 1979 Code; 2018 Code)
3-2-29: COMPENSATION OF LIQUOR COMMISSIONER:
The Mayor as Liquor Commissioner shall receive as compensation for his services
as Commissioner the sum of one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) per
year, payable monthly, such compensation to become effective May 1, 2001. (Ord.
2000-09, 10-17-2000)
CHAPTER 3
SOLICITORS AND CANVASSERS
SECTION:
3-3-1: Registration Required
3-3-2: Application
3-3-3: Fee
3-3-4: Certificate
3-3-5: House To House Canvassing, Soliciting
3-3-6: Exceptions
3-3-7: Acts Prohibited
3-3-8: Revocation
3-3-9: Penalty
3-3-1: REGISTRATION REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in business as a canvasser or
solicitor calling at residences for the purpose of soliciting orders, sales,
subscriptions or business of any kind, or seeking for information or donations,
without first having registered in the Office of the City Clerk. The registrant
shall give his complete identification, his signature, the name of his
employer, the nature of the products or services in which he is interested, the
names of the manufacturers of such products, or of the organization which he is
representing and the proposed method of operation in the City. (Ord. 749, 1964)
3-3-2: APPLICATION:
Any person desiring to secure such a solicitor's permit shall apply therefor in
writing over his signature to the City Clerk on forms provided by the City, and
such applicant shall complete all information required on the application
including:
   (A)   The name and address of the applicant.
   (B)   The name and address of the person, firm or corporation by whom
employed.
   (C)   The length of service of such applicant with such employer.
   (D)   The place of residence and nature of the employment of the applicant
during at least the preceding year.
   (E)   The nature or character of the goods, wares, merchandise or services
to be offered by the applicant.
   (F)   The personal description of the applicant.
Such an application shall be accompanied by a two inch by two inch (2" x 2")
full face photograph and such other credentials and other evidence of good
moral character and identity of the applicant may be reasonably required by the
City Clerk. (Ord. 749, 1964)
Any person that is registered as a sex offender in any jurisdiction or has had
a felony conviction in any jurisdiction shall be ineligible for a solicitors/
canvassers permit from the City of Carthage. (Ord. 2008-3, 6-24-2008)
3-3-3: FEE:
The fee for registration as a solicitor/canvasser shall be one hundred dollars
($100.00) for a term of five (5) days and the hours of solicitation within the
City of Carthage shall be from eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. to five o'clock (5:00)
P.M. Charitable organizations shall be exempt from the fee but shall comply
with the hours of solicitation. (Ord. 2013-3, 6-25-2013)
3-3-4: CERTIFICATE:
Each person shall at all times while soliciting or canvassing in the City carry
upon his person the registration certificate and the same shall be exhibited by
such registrant whenever he is required to do so by any police officer or other
person solicited. (Ord. 749, 1964)
3-3-5: HOUSE TO HOUSE CANVASSING, SOLICITING:
It shall be unlawful to engage in the business of going upon the premises of
another for the purpose of soliciting orders, contributions or information, or
for the purpose of selling or peddling, without the consent or invitation of
the owner or occupant of such premises. The fact that such canvasser, solicitor
or peddler is a resident of the Municipality, or the employee or proprietor of
a business established in the Municipality, shall be prima facie proof that the
owner or occupant of such premises has given the consent required. (Ord. 749,
1964)
3-3-6: EXCEPTIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to officers or employees of the
City, County, State or Federal government or any subdivision thereof when on
official business. (Ord. 749, 1964)
3-3-7: ACTS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to whom a registration certificate has been
issued hereunder, to force his way into a home or place of business for the
purpose of solicitation against the will of the person in charge thereof, or to
make a nuisance of himself to the occupant or occupants thereof; and further,
in case any such person so soliciting shall be requested to leave any premises
where he is soliciting business by the person in charge thereof, he shall leave
such premises promptly. It shall be unlawful for any person soliciting business
under a registration certificate, issued hereunder, to resort to any fraud,
cheating or misrepresentation in connection with such solicitation; or to
solicit a sale of anything not specified in his application for a certificate
or to violate any laws of the Federal, State or City governments. (1979 Code)
3-3-8: REVOCATION:
Any such registration may be revoked by the Mayor or Chief of Police because of
any violation by the registrant of this chapter, or of any of the provisions of
this Code, or of any State or Federal law, or whenever the registrant shall
cease to possess the qualifications and character required in this chapter for
the original registration. Such revocation shall be in addition to any fine
imposed hereunder. (1979 Code)
3-3-9: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter, unless otherwise
provided, shall be fined not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more
than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense; and a separate offense
shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or
continues. (1979 Code; amd. 2018 Code)
CHAPTER 4
PUBLIC CARRIERS
SECTION:
3-4-1: Definition
3-4-2: License Required
3-4-3: Character Of Applicant
3-4-4: Public Carrier Fee
3-4-5: Vehicles
3-4-6: Drivers
3-4-7: Insurance
3-4-8: Bond
3-4-9: Traffic Rules
3-4-10: Unlawful Use
3-4-11: Passengers
3-4-12: Payment Of Fare
3-4-13: Fares
3-4-14: Chauffeur's License
3-4-15: Chauffeur's License Fee
3-4-16: Qualifications
3-4-17: Revocation
3-4-18: Abandonment
3-4-19: Number Of Licenses
3-4-1: DEFINITION:
The term "public carrier" as used in this chapter shall mean and include any
vehicle used to carry passengers for hire but not operating a fixed route.
(1979 Code)
3-4-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to engage in the business of operating a public carrier in
the Municipality without first having secured a license therefor. Applications
for such license shall be made in writing to the Clerk, and shall state thereon
the name of the applicant, the intended place of business and the number of
public carriers to be operated. If the applicant is a corporation, the names
and addresses of the president and secretary thereof shall be given. (1979
Code)
3-4-3: CHARACTER OF APPLICANT:
No such license shall be issued to or held by any person who is not a person of
good character or who has been convicted of a felony; nor shall such license be
issued to or held by any corporation if any other thereof would be ineligible
for a license under the foregoing conditions. (1979 Code)
3-4-4: PUBLIC CARRIER FEE:
The annual fee for such licenses shall be ten dollars fifty cents ($10.50) for
each public carrier operated. Whenever the number of public carriers so
operated shall be increased during the license year, the licensee shall notify
the Clerk of such change and shall pay the additional fee.
Such fee shall be in lieu of any other vehicle fee required by this Code and
the Clerk shall issue suitable tags or stickers for the number of public
carriers covered by each license. Such tag or sticker shall be displayed in a
prominent place on each public carrier while it is in use and may be
transferred to any public carrier put into service to replace one withdrawn
from service.
The licensee shall notify the Clerk of the motor number and State license
number of each public carrier operated and of the corresponding Municipal tag
or sticker number. (1979 Code)
3-4-5: VEHICLES:
No public carrier shall be operated unless it bears a State license duly
issued; and no such public carrier shall be operated unless it is equipped with
proper brakes, lights, tires, horn, muffler, rear vision mirror, and windshield
wipers in good condition. It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police or his
Deputy to inspect every public carrier, each ninety (90) days, to see to the
enforcement of the provisions of this chapter.
Each public carrier, while operated, shall have on each side, in letters
readable from a distance of twenty feet (20'), the name of the licensee
operating it. If more than one public carrier is operated by the licensee, each
public carrier shall be designated by a different number, and such number shall
so appear on each side of such public carrier. (1979 Code)
3-4-6: DRIVERS:
No person shall drive a public carrier or be hired or permitted to do so,
unless he is duly licensed as a chauffeur.
It shall be unlawful for any driver of a public carrier, while on duty, to
drink any intoxicating liquor, or to use any profane or obscene language, to
shout or call to prospective passengers, or to disturb the peace in any way.
(1979 Code)
3-4-7: INSURANCE:
No public carrier shall be operated unless it is covered by a bond or public
liability policy as required by the Statutes of the State of Illinois. (1979
Code)
3-4-8: BOND:
Every person taking out a public carrier license as provided in this chapter,
before operating any public carrier, shall execute a bond to the City in the
sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each vehicle, with two (2) or more
sureties to be approved by the Mayor, conditioned for the faithful performance
of his duties as owner or operator of said public carrier, and that he will
account for and pay all damages arising from any neglect on his part or on the
part of any employee while so engaged in the operation of the public carrier
business. (1979 Code)
3-4-9: TRAFFIC RULES:
It shall be the duty of every driver of a public carrier to obey all traffic
rules established by statute or provisions of this Code 1 . (1979 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 9 of this Code.
3-4-10: UNLAWFUL USE:
It shall be unlawful to knowingly permit any public carrier to be used in the
perpetration of a crime or misdemeanor. (1979 Code)
3-4-11: PASSENGERS:
It shall be the duty of the driver of any public carrier to accept as a
passenger any person who seeks to so use the public carrier, provided such
person is not intoxicated and conducts himself in an orderly manner. (1979
Code)
3-4-12: PAYMENT OF FARE:
It shall be unlawful for a passenger to fail or refuse to pay the lawful fare
at the termination of a trip. (1979 Code)
3-4-13: FARES:
Any person operating a public carrier within the City shall establish and file
with the City Clerk a rate for the hauling of passengers, and said rates shall
be uniform as to all persons. The rates shall also be posted in each so as to
be plainly visible to the passengers. No extra charge shall be made for baggage
or parcels the size of which permits them to be carried in the public carrier
by the passenger. (1979 Code)
3-4-14: CHAUFFEUR'S LICENSE:
No person shall drive a public carrier unless he shall have secured a license
therefor as herein provided. (1979 Code)
3-4-15: CHAUFFEUR'S LICENSE FEE:
The annual fee for a chauffeur's license shall be one dollar ($1.00). (1979
Code)
3-4-16: QUALIFICATIONS:
No such license shall be issued to any person who is not competent to operate a
motor vehicle or who is not familiar with the traffic laws and Code provisions.
The Chief of Police shall examine each applicant for a chauffeur's license to
determine the competency of the applicant, and no such license shall be issued
excepting on certificate of the Chief of Police that the applicant has
demonstrated his ability to operate a motor vehicle as required herein. (1979
Code)
3-4-17: REVOCATION:
The Mayor may revoke any chauffeur's license for repeated violations of traffic
laws or Code provisions regulating the conduct of such drivers. (1979 Code)
3-4-18: ABANDONMENT:
If any licensee shall fail to operate all or any of the public carriers covered
by such license for a period of ten (10) consecutive days, the certificate may
be revoked or modified by the Mayor so as to cover and authorize only the
number of public carriers actually operated. Failure to operate any public
carriers by a licensee for a period of ten (10) consecutive days shall be
grounds for revocation of the public carrier license. (1979 Code)
3-4-19: NUMBER OF LICENSES:
The number of public carrier licenses to be issued is limited to four (4). Each
licensee shall have the right to operate as many as ten (10) public carriers
under the one license. As long as the population of the City remains at ten
thousand (10,000) or under, the limitation shall apply. In the event that the
population in the City shall exceed ten thousand (10,000) the number of
licenses may increase not to exceed one license for each one thousand (1,000)
population in excess of ten thousand (10,000). (1979 Code)
CHAPTER 5
MUNICIPAL OCCUPATION TAXES
SECTION:
3-5-1: Retailers' Occupation Tax
3-5-2: Service Occupation Tax
3-5-3: Use Tax
3-5-4: Nonhome Rule Occupation Taxes
3-5-1: RETAILERS' OCCUPATION TAX:
A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of selling
tangible personal property at retail in the City at the rate of one percent
(1%) of the gross receipts from such sales made in the course of such business
while this section is in effect, in accordance with the provisions of section
8-11-1 of the Illinois Municipal Code.
Every such person engaged in such business in the City shall file on or before
the last day of each calendar month, the report to the State Department of
Revenue required by section three of "An Act in Relation to a Tax Upon Persons
Engaged in the Business of Selling Tangible Personal Property to Purchasers for
Use or Consumption" approved June 28, 1933, as amended.
At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the State Department
of Revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account of the receipts from
sales of tangible personal property during the preceding month. (Ord. 69-14, 8-
4-1969)
3-5-2: SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX:
A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in this Municipality in the
business of making sales of service at the rate of one percent (1%) of the cost
price of all tangible personal property transferred by said servicemen either
in the form of tangible personal property or in the form of real estate as an
incident to a sale of service, in accordance with the provisions of section 8-
11-5 of the Illinois Municipal Code.
Every supplier or serviceman required to account for Municipal Service
Occupation Tax for the benefit of this Municipality shall file, on or before
the last day of each calendar month, the report to the State Department of
Revenue required by section nine of the "Service Occupation Tax Act", approved
July 10, 1961, as amended.
At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the State Department
of Revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed. (Ord. 69-15, 8-4-1969)
3-5-3: USE TAX:
There is hereby imposed a tax in accordance with the provisions of section 8-
11-6 of the Illinois Municipal Code upon the privilege of using in the
Municipality any item of tangible personal property which is purchased outside
Illinois at retail from a retailer, and which is titled or registered with an
agency of Illinois government, the tax shall be at a rate of one percent (1%)
of the selling price of such tangible property with the selling price to have
the meaning as defined in the Use Tax Act approved July 14, 1955.
Such tax shall be collected by the Illinois Department of Revenue for all
municipalities imposing the tax and shall be paid before the title or
certificate of registration for the personal property is issued. (Ord. 74-9,
10-21-1974)
3-5-4: NONHOME RULE OCCUPATION TAXES:
   (A)   Imposition Of Tax: A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in
the business of selling tangible personal property, other than an item of
tangible personal property titled and registered with an agency of this State's
government, at retail in the City of Carthage at the rate of one-half (1/2) of
one percent (1%) as gross receipts from such sale made in the course of such
business while this section is in effect; and a tax is hereby imposed upon all
persons engaged in this Municipality in the business of making sales of
service, at the rate of one-half (1/2) of one percent (1%) of the selling price
of all tangible personal property transferred by such servicemen as an incident
to a sale of service. Such "Nonhome Rule Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax"
and the "Nonhome Rule Municipal Service Occupation Tax" shall not be applicable
to the sales of food for human consumption that is to be consumed off the
premises where it is sold (other than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks and food
that has been prepared for immediate consumption) and prescription and
nonprescription medicines, drugs, medical appliances and insulin, urine testing
materials, syringes and needles used by diabetics.
The imposition of these Nonhome Rule Taxes is in accordance with the provisions
of sections 5/8-11-1.3 and 5/8-11-1.4, respectively, of the "Illinois Municipal
Code" 1 .
   (B)   Collection And Enforcement: The taxes hereby imposed, and all civil
penalties that may be assessed as an incident thereto, shall be collected and
enforced by the Department of Revenue of the State of Illinois. The Department
of Revenue shall have full power to administer and enforce provisions of this
section.
   (C)   Certified Copy: The City Clerk of the City of Carthage is hereby
directed to file a certified copy of the ordinance codified herein and a
certification that the ordinance codified herein received referendum approval
with the Illinois Department of Revenue on or before October 1, 2003.
   (D)   Effective Date: This section shall take effect on the next January 1,
(January 1, 2004) following the adoption and filing of the ordinance codified
herein with the Department of Revenue. (Ord. 2003-2, 5-13-2003)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.3 and 5/8-11-1.4.
CHAPTER 6
ALARMS
SECTION:
3-6-1: Fire Notifications System Nuisance Alarms
3-6-1-1: Fire Notification Fees
3-6-2: Police Notification System Nuisance Alarms
3-6-2-1: Police Notification Fees
3-6-1: FIRE NOTIFICATIONS SYSTEM NUISANCE ALARMS:
The Fire Department of the City of Carthage shall impose no charge for
responding to nuisance alarms to businesses within the City with automated fire
notifications systems for the first three (3) such nuisance alarms in any
twelve (12) consecutive month period.
It shall be the responsibility of any business in the City of Carthage
utilizing an automated fire notification system to provide the name and a
twenty four (24) hour call number of their contact person to the Hancock County
911 Center. It will be the responsibility of the business to have a contact
person on the scene within thirty (30) minutes. (Ord. 2010-7, 10-26-2010)
3-6-1-1: FIRE NOTIFICATION FEES:
Any business in the City of Carthage utilizing an automated fire notification
system generating more than three (3) nuisance alarms in any twelve (12)
consecutive month period shall be assessed a fee in the sum of four hundred
fifty dollars ($450.00) for each nuisance alarm in which the Fire Department
proceeds to the scene, exceeding three (3) nuisance alarms in any twelve (12)
consecutive month period.
If the contact person is not at the scene within thirty (30) minutes of the
Fire Department arriving at the scene, a fee of two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) will be assessed.
The Fire Chief shall notify the City Clerk of occurrences of such nuisance
alarms, and the City Clerk shall maintain the records thereof and for any such
nuisance alarms exceeding three (3) days in any twelve (12) consecutive month
period, shall bill appropriate charges within seven (7) days from the time they
are incurred. (Ord. 2010-7, 10-26-2010)
3-6-2: POLICE NOTIFICATION SYSTEM NUISANCE ALARMS:
The Police Department of the City of Carthage shall impose no charge for
responding to nuisance alarms to businesses within the City with the automated
police notification system for the first three (3) such nuisance alarms in any
twelve (12) consecutive month period.
It shall be the responsibility of any business in the City of Carthage
utilizing an automated police notification system to provide the name and a
twenty four (24) hour call number of their contact person to the Hancock County
911 Center. It will be the responsibility of the business to have a contact
person on the scene within thirty (30) minutes. (Ord. 2010-7, 10-26-2010)
3-6-2-1: POLICE NOTIFICATION FEES:
Any business in the City of Carthage utilizing an automated police notification
system generating more than three (3) nuisance alarms in any twelve (12)
consecutive month period shall be assessed a fee in the sum of four hundred
fifty dollars ($450.00) for each nuisance alarm in which the Police Department
proceeds to the scene, exceeding three (3) nuisance alarms in any twelve (12)
consecutive month period.
If the contact person is not at the scene within thirty (30) minutes of the
Police Department arriving at the scene, a fee of two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) will be assessed.
The Police Chief shall notify the City Clerk of all occurrences of such
nuisance alarms, and the City Clerk shall maintain the records thereof and for
any such nuisance alarms exceeding three (3) in any twelve (12) consecutive
month period, and shall bill appropriate charges within seven (7) days from the
time they are incurred. (Ord. 2010-7, 10-26-2010)
CHAPTER 7
VIDEO GAMING
SECTION:
3-7-1: Video Gaming Terminals
3-7-1: VIDEO GAMING TERMINALS:
Gaming terminals for which a license or permit has been issued by the Illinois
Gaming Board pursuant to the Illinois Gaming Act 1 , as amended from time to
time, are hereby authorized within the City of Carthage, so long as such video
gaming terminals are operated in compliance with all requirements of the
Illinois Video Gaming Act and all applicable rules and regulations of the
Illinois Gaming Board. An annual fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) per video
gaming terminal shall be paid to the City by the terminal operator. (Ord. 2012-
4, 7-10-2012)
 
Notes
1 1. 230 ILCS 40/1 et seq.
CHAPTER 8
MUNICIPAL CANNABIS RETAILERS’ OCCUPATION TAX
SECTION:
3-8-1: Tax Imposed; Rate
3-8-2: Collection Of Tax By Retailers
3-8-1: TAX IMPOSED; RATE:
   (A)   A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of
selling cannabis, other than cannabis purchased under the Compassionate Use of
Medical Cannabis Pilot Program Act, at retail in the City of Carthage at the
rate of three percent (3%) of the gross receipts from these sales made in the
course of that business.
   (B)   The imposition of this tax is in accordance with the provisions of
section 8-11-22 of the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/8-11-22. (Ord. 2019-10, 12-10-2019)
3-8-2: COLLECTION OF TAX BY RETAILERS:
   (A)   The tax imposed by this chapter shall be remitted by such retailer to
the Illinois Department of Revenue. Any tax required to be collected pursuant
to or as authorized by this chapter and any such tax collected by such retailer
and required to be remitted to the Department shall constitute a debt owed by
the retailer to the state. Retailers may reimburse themselves for their
seller’s tax liability hereunder by separate stating that tax as an additional
charge, which charge may be stated in combination, in a single amount, with any
state tax that sellers are required to collect.
   (B)   The taxes hereby imposed and all civil penalties that may be assessed
as an incident thereto, shall be collected and enforced by the Department. The
Department shall have full power to administer and enforce the provisions of
this chapter. (Ord. 2019-10, 12-10-2019)

3-9-2: Cannabis Business Establishments Prohibited
3-9-3: Public Nuisance Declared

3-9-2: CANNABIS BUSINESS ESTABLISHMENTS PROHIBITED:
The following adult-use cannabis business establishments are prohibited in the
City of Carthage. No person shall locate, operate, own, suffer, allow to be
operated or aide, abet or assist in the operation within the City of Carthage
of any of the following:
   (A)   Adult-use cannabis craft grower;
   (B)   Adult-use cannabis cultivation center;
   (C)   Adult-use cannabis dispensing organization;
   (D)   Adult-use cannabis infuser organization or infuser;
   (E)   Adult-use cannabis processing organization or processor;
   (F)   Adult-use cannabis transporting organization or transporter. (Ord.
2019-11, 12-10-2019)
3-9-3: PUBLIC NUISANCE DECLARED:
Operation of any prohibited cannabis business establishment within the City of
Carthage in violation of the provisions of this chapter is hereby declared a
public nuisance and shall be abated pursuant to all available remedies. (Ord.
2019-11, 12-10-2019)
3-9-4: VIOLATIONS:
Violations of this chapter may be enforced in accordance with the provisions of
this chapter and are subject to a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per
day of violation. (Ord. 2019-11, 12-10-2019)
CHAPTER 10
TRANSIENT FOOD VENDORS
SECTION:
3-10-1: Mobile Food Vendors
3-10-2: Prohibited Conduct
3-10-3: Criminal Penalty
3-10-4: Requirements
3-10-1: MOBILE FOOD VENDORS:
   A.   Mobile food vendor operational requirements. Mobile food vendors
conducting business within the city must comply with the following
requirements:
      1.   All transient food vendors must abide by all federal, state and
local laws, rules and regulations. Mobile food vendors must operate in
compliance with all state laws and regulations and must maintain continuous
licensure with the Hancock County Health Department.
      2.   Mobile food vendors may vend only on private property with the
consent of the property owner and may not encroach into any right-of-way
adjoining the property with the mobile food vending establishment or utilize
any accessory items such as tables, chairs, etc. Mobile food vendors may not
operate on city property or within the right-of way. If requested by the city,
a mobile food vendor shall promptly provide proof of a property owner's consent
to operate on the property.
      3.   Mobile food vending is allowed as a necessary use in the following
situations:
         a.   On a parcel with a commercial or industrial use;
         b.   On a construction site to fulfill on-site needs;
         c.   In a residential zoning District if in conjunction with a special
event held at a non-residential structure;
         d.   As otherwise authorized by the City of Carthage.
      4.   The vendor shall not conduct any vending in a way that causes
congestion or blocking of vehicle or pedestrian traffic or emergency lanes.
Each vendor has an affirmative and independent duty to determine the safety and
suitability of any particular location of operation and to operate in a manner
reasonably calculated to avoid and prevent harm to people and to other
vehicles.
      5.   All areas within and surrounding a mobile food service establishment
must be maintained in a clean, neat, and sanitary condition. A mobile food
vendor shall provide Uprivate trash bin for public use with a capacity of no
less 32 gallons each which shall be removed upon departing the location and the
contents disposed of properly by the vendor. Trash bins shall be anchored or
otherwise secured upright. A mobile food vendor shall remove all litter
generated by its operation at the vendor's expense. The mobile food vendor
shall not place trash or litter from the mobile food vending establishment in
any unauthorized private or city receptacle.
      6.   Umbrellas and canopies must be designed to be secure during windy
conditions. Umbrellas and canopies must be at least seven (7) feet above the
ground when open and may not protrude into the right-of-way.
      7.   All mobile food vendors must ensure that individuals with
disabilities have comparable access to mobile food vending establishment. If
existing designs cannot be modified to be accessible to people with
disabilities, the method of providing service must be modified to become
accessible.
      8.   A mobile food vending establishment cannot be permanently located on
any property and cannot function as a permanent structure.
      9.   Mobile food vendors may not vend alcohol. (Ord. 2022-3, 5-24-2022)
3-10-2: PROHIBITED CONDUCT:
No mobile food vendor shall:
   A.   Vend in the public right-of-way, including on any public street, alley,
sidewalk, or in any on-street parking space, except in the following situation:
      1.   In conjunction with a special event that is approved by the city, if
applicable, so long as the special event includes the closure of the public
right-of-way and consents to the presence of the mobile food vendor; or
      2.   In limited situations with the approval of the City Council of the
City of Carthage;
   B.   Operate a mobile food establishment within 300 feet of any event held
in the Central Business District without obtaining written permission form the
event sponsor and the City;
   C.   Place any object that blocks any pedestrian pathway or ADA access;
   D.   Utilize any signage other than signage that is affixed to the exterior
of the mobile food vending establishment other than 1 sandwich board sign may
be allowed;
   E.   Project audible amplified music or sound or make any unreasonably loud
noise for the purpose of advertising or attracting attention to the mobile food
vending establishment. (Ord. 2022-3, 5-24-2022)
3-10-3: CRIMINAL PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter
shall be subject to a fine of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) for each offense
plus costs to the city including attorneys fees. Each day of violation shall
constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 2022-3, 5-24-2022)
3-10-4: REQUIREMENTS:
Each mobile food vendor shall apply for a permit issued by the City Clerk. The
City Clerk shall issue a permit upon receiving from the mobile food vendor
applicant copies of:
   A.   The vendors Hancock County Health Department permit;
   B.   The vendor's Illinois Sales Tax ID number;
   C.   Proof of Insurance;
   D.   Payment of a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for a one-year permit. The
permit must be always prominently displayed while vending. (Ord. 2022-3, 5-24-
2022)
TITLE 4
BUILDING REGULATIONS
Building Codes   1
Dangerous Buildings   2
Moving Buildings   3
Flood Damage Prevention   4
CHAPTER 1
BUILDING CODES
SECTION:
4-1-1: Codes Adopted
4-1-2: Enforcement
4-1-3: Modifications
4-1-4: Appeals
4-1-5: Permits
4-1-5-1: Demolition Permits
4-1-6: Fees
4-1-7: Conflicting Provisions
4-1-8: Penalties
4-1-1: CODES ADOPTED:
   (A)   Building Code: There is hereby adopted for the purpose of establishing
rules and regulations for the construction, alteration, removal, demolition,
equipment, use and occupancy, location and maintenance of buildings and
structures, that certain Building Code known as the "Uniform Building Code",
copyrighted by the International Conference of Building Officials, the latest
edition, as amended thereof, of which not less than three (3) copies have been
and now are filed in the Office of the Clerk, and the same are hereby adopted
and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein and the provisions
thereof shall be controlling in the construction of all buildings and other
structures.
   (B)   Uniform Housing Code: In order to provide minimum requirements for the
protection of life, limb, health, property, safety and welfare of the general
public and the owners and occupants of residential buildings, there is hereby
adopted by the City that certain code known as the "Uniform Housing Code", the
latest edition, published by the International Conference of Building Officials
which provisions and regulations thereof shall apply to all buildings or
portions thereof used, or designed or intended to be used, for human
habitation.
   (C)   Plumbing Code: There is hereby adopted for the purpose of establishing
minimum standards of design, materials and workmanship for all plumbing
hereafter installed, altered or repaired and to establish methods of procedure
within the limits of the City that certain Plumbing Code known as the "National
Plumbing Code", the latest copyright edition thereof, and the whole thereof of
which not less than three (3) copies have been and now are filed in the Office
of the Clerk, and the same are hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if
set out at length herein, and from the date on which this chapter shall take
effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling in the installation,
alteration or repairing of plumbing.
   (D)   Electrical Code: All electric wiring, installation of electrical
fixtures, apparatus, or electrical appliances for furnishing light, heat or
power, or other electrical work introduced into or placed in or upon, or in any
way connected to, any building or structure within the limits of this City
shall be in conformity with the provisions set forth in the latest edition of
the "National Electrical Code", as amended, recommended by the American
Insurance Association for electrical wiring and apparatus, which is hereby
adopted and incorporated as a part of this Code as fully as if set out at
length herein, three (3) copies of said Electrical Code shall at all times be
on file in the Office of the Clerk.
Wherever the word "Municipality" is used in the codes hereby adopted, it shall
be held to mean the City of Carthage. (1979 Code)
4-1-2: ENFORCEMENT:
The codes hereby adopted shall be enforced by the Codes Enforcement Officer who
shall be appointed as provided by these codes, who is authorized by this
section to make inspections to determine the condition of dwellings located
within jurisdiction of this chapter and who is to generally administer the
enforcement of this chapter in all respects. (1979 Code)
4-1-3: MODIFICATIONS:
The Codes Enforcement Officer shall have power to modify any of the provisions
of the codes hereby adopted upon application in writing by the owner or lessee,
or his duly authorized agent, when there are practical difficulties in the way
of carrying out the strict letter of the codes, provided that the spirit of the
codes shall be observed, public safety secured, and substantial justice done.
The particulars of such modification when granted or allowed and the decision
of the Codes Enforcement Officer thereon shall be entered upon the records to
be kept by the Codes Enforcement Officer and a signed copy shall be furnished
the applicant. (Ord. 69-3, 5-5-1969; amd. 1979 Code)
4-1-4: APPEALS:
Whenever the Codes Enforcement Officer shall disapprove an application or
refuse to grant a permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the provisions
of any of the codes do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the
codes have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal
from the decision of the Codes Enforcement Officer to the City Council within
thirty (30) days from the date of the decision appealed. (Ord. 69-3, 5-5-1969;
amd. 1979 Code)
4-1-5: PERMITS:
Prior to the commencement of the construction of a new building, structure or
parking lot, or the enlargement or alteration of a building or structure, the
owner or lessor, or his duly authorized agent shall file a written application
for a building permit in the Office of the City Clerk, which application shall
state the address at which such building, enlargement or alteration of a
building or structure or such parking lot shall be made, the type of building,
enlargement or alteration, whether electrical or plumbing work shall be
performed, the date when actual work shall be commenced and the estimated cost
of the materials and labor to be expended in connection with such building,
enlargement or alteration. There shall be attached to said written application
a detailed statement of specifications and plans that shall comply with the
codes referred to in section
4-1-1 of this chapter. Upon approval, the Codes Enforcement Officer of the City
shall issue to each applicant, under the terms of this chapter, a permit for
the construction of a new building or structure or the enlargement or
alteration of an existing building or structure, such permit to be in the form
as designated by the Utilities Committee of the City Council. (Ord. 69-3, 5-5-
1969; amd. 1979 Code)
In connection with the construction of a new building, structure or parking
lot, or the enlargement, alteration or removal of a building or structure, the
person obtaining a permit as required by this section shall, more than twenty
four (24) hours prior to the tapping or disconnecting of any water or sewer
main within the City, give oral notice to the Superintendent of the Waterworks
and Sewerage Department of the City of the time and date that such water or
sewer main shall be tapped into or disconnected from. Any person tapping into
or disconnecting from such water or sewer main shall comply with the provisions
set forth in section
 8-1-2 of this Code. (Ord. 806, 9-5-1967; amd. 1979 Code)
4-1-5-1: DEMOLITION PERMITS:
Prior to the commencement of the demolition of any building or structure, the
owner or lessor, or his duly authorized agent shall file a written application
for a demolition permit in the Office of the City Clerk, which application
shall state the address of the building or structure to be demolished, the type
of building or structure, whether the building or structure is served by water
and/or sewer, and the date when actual demolition work shall commence. Upon
payment of the prescribed fee, the application shall be approved by the Codes
Enforcement Officer who shall issue a permit for the demolition, such permit to
be in the form as designated by the Utilities Committee of the City Council.
All electrical and gas utilities shall be terminated and disconnected by the
utility company at the applicant's request and expense, and water service to
the building or structure shall be shut off and approved by the Water
Superintendent before demolition may commence.
The application shall require the applicant to complete the demolition and
cleanup of the property within six (6) months of the date of the application,
shall require the applicant to disconnect any water service to the building or
structure and have it capped at the main by a licensed plumber at applicant's
expense, and shall require the applicant to disconnect any sewer service to the
building or structure and have it capped at the main by a licensed plumber at
applicant's expense, within six (6) months of issuance of the permit.
In the event the applicant intends to rebuild, the Codes Enforcement Officer
may extend the time to cap the water and sewer an additional twelve (12) months
from the date of the application.
The fee for a demolition permit shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00) in the
event there is neither water nor sewer to the building or structure, and one
hundred dollars ($100.00) if there is either water or sewer to the building or
structure. (Ord. 2011-6, 9-27-2011)

4-1-7: CONFLICTING PROVISIONS:
In any case where a provision of this chapter is found to be in conflict with
the provisions of any zoning, building, fire, safety or health ordinance or
code existing on the effective date hereof, the provision which establishes the
higher standard for the promotion and protection of the health and safety of
the people shall prevail. In any case where a provision of this chapter is
found to be in conflict with the provisions of any other ordinance or code on
the effective date hereof which establishes a lower standard for the promotion
and protection of the health and safety of the people, the provisions of this
chapter shall be deemed to prevail, and such other ordinances or codes are
hereby declared to be repealed to the extent that they may be found in conflict
with this chapter. If any section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause or
phrase of this chapter should be declared invalid for any reason, such decision
shall not affect the remaining portions of this chapter, which shall remain in
full force and effect; and to this end the provisions of this chapter are
hereby declared to be severable. (Ord. 69-3, 5-5-1969)
4-1-8: PENALTIES:
Any person who shall violate any provisions of the codes hereby adopted or fail
to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any order made
thereunder, or who shall build in violation of any detailed statement of
specification or plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any certificate or
permit issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been taken, or who shall
fail to comply with such an order as affirmed or modified by the City Council
or by a court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed herein, shall
severally for each and every such violation and noncompliance respectively, be
guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not less than seventy five
dollars ($75.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). The imposition of
one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to
continue; and all such persons shall be required to correct or remedy such
violation or defects within a reasonable time; and when not otherwise
specified, each day that prohibited conditions are maintained shall constitute
a separate offense. (Ord. 69-3, 5-5-1969; amd. 2018 Code)
The application of the above penalty shall not be held to prevent the enforced
removal of prohibited conditions.
An occupancy permit shall not be granted to any person in violation hereof.
(Ord. 69-3, 5-5-1969)
CHAPTER 2
DANGEROUS BUILDINGS
SECTION:
4-2-1: Dangerous Buildings; Nuisance
4-2-2: Report Dangerous Buildings
4-2-3: Proceedings
4-2-4: Action To Prevent Accident
4-2-5: Building May Be Closed
4-2-6: Repairing
4-2-7: Penalty
4-2-1: DANGEROUS BUILDINGS; NUISANCE:
Any building or part thereof, or any structure of like nature, in a condition
dangerous to the occupants, or those passing, or to any adjacent building, by
reason of bad conditions of walls, overloaded floors, defective heating
apparatus, violations from machinery, defective flues, confined or cramped
stairways, insufficient exits, narrow or dark passageways, or which is unsafe
or dangerous for the purpose for which it is used or intended to be used, or is
in danger of being set on fire from any defect in its construction or is
especially dangerous in case of fire by reason of its dilapidated condition or
defective construction, or from other causes, or which may be prejudicial to
the public health or the health of the inhabitants of the neighborhood, shall
be deemed and is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. (1979 Code)
4-2-2: REPORT DANGEROUS BUILDINGS:
Whenever it shall come to the knowledge of the Codes Enforcement Officer, Fire
Chief, Health Officer, or complaint shall be made to them or any of them in
writing by any two (2) reputable citizens, that any building, walls or
structure within the Village is in such dangerous condition as described in the
preceding section, said Codes Enforcement Officer, Fire Chief or Health
Officer, as the case may be, shall forthwith report the same to the City
Council. (1979 Code)
4-2-3: PROCEEDINGS:
Whenever it shall come to the knowledge of the Codes Enforcement Officer,
Police Chief, Health Officer or complainant that a building be in a dangerous
and unsafe condition, the Mayor or any official or employee designated by the
City Council shall notify in writing the owner or owners thereof, directing
said owner or owners to put such building in a safe condition or demolish it.
Where, upon diligent search the identity or whereabouts of the owner or owners
of any such building shall not be ascertainable, such notice shall be mailed to
the person or persons in whose name such real estate was last assessed.
If, after fifteen (15) days subsequent to the giving of such notice, said owner
or owners fail to put such building in a safe condition or to demolish it, the
Mayor or any official or employee designated by the City Council shall so
notify the City Attorney requesting the City Attorney to apply on behalf of the
City to the Circuit Court of Hancock County, Illinois, for an order authorizing
the City to demolish or repair or to cause the demolition or repair of said
building.
The costs of such demolition or repair shall be recoverable from the owner or
owners of such real estate and shall be a lien thereon as provided in chapter
65, section 5/11-31-1 of the Illinois Compiled Statutes in such cases as made
and provided. (1979 Code)
4-2-4: ACTION TO PREVENT ACCIDENT:
In case the Codes Enforcement Officer or Health Officer finds any building or
part of a building in such condition as to endanger life or liable to cause
serious accident, and that such danger may be averted by the immediate
application of precautionary measures, said officers or either of them shall
have and exercise the power (without the preliminary direction of the City
Council), to take such precautionary measures as in his opinion may be
necessary to render any building or part thereof safe; provided, the owner,
lessee, occupant or agent of said building refuses or neglects to take such
precautionary measures after being notified so to do by said officers or any of
them. The decision and order of the said officers or any of them, as the case
may be, shall be absolute and final. (1979 Code)
4-2-5: BUILDING MAY BE CLOSED:
The Codes Enforcement Officer, Health Officer or Fire Chief may order that no
person shall be permitted to enter, occupy or use a dangerous building or any
portion thereof until the same shall have been made safe; and may post such
order in a conspicuous place on the exterior wall of such building. No person
shall enter, occupy or use (except for the purpose of repairing and making
safe) any building or portion thereof after the posting of such notice until
such building or portion thereof shall have been made safe.
If the building or portion thereof found dangerous shall be devoted to any
purpose requiring a license, the Mayor may suspend the license pending the
period of making repairs; and he may revoke the license in case of failure on
the part of the owner or party having an interest in such unsafe building or
portion thereof to make such repairs without delay and at their expense. (1979
Code)
4-2-6: REPAIRING:
It shall not be lawful to occupy for human habitation any building which is
declared by the Health Officer to be unfit for such habitation by reason of
defective sanitary conditions until such conditions have been remedied and the
premises approved by said Health Officer as fit for occupancy.
If work has been done and expense incurred by the City in connection with
dangerous buildings a bill of cost shall be rendered by the City to the owner,
lessee, occupant or agent of the property. The City may refuse to issue a
permit for the reconstruction, alteration or repair of any building or portion
thereof on the property involved until the expenditure incurred by the City on
account of the work and material supplied has been repaid. (1979 Code)
4-2-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter or permitting any dangerous
building or any other man-made structure to remain in a dangerous condition
shall be fined not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) or more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense; and a separate offense shall be
deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or
continues. (1979 Code; amd. 2018 Code)
CHAPTER 3
MOVING BUILDINGS
SECTION:
4-3-1: Permit Required
4-3-2: Approval; Fee
4-3-3: Bond
4-3-4: Lights And Warnings
4-3-5: Wires, Cutting
4-3-6: Fire Alarm Wires
4-3-7: Damage To City Property
4-3-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person shall move any building on, through or over any street, alley,
sidewalk or other public place in the City without having obtained a permit
therefor from the Code Enforcement Officer. Applications for such permit shall
be made in writing and shall state thereon the purposed route and the number of
days it is intended that the building shall occupy any portion of any street,
alley, sidewalk or other public place. (Ord. 89-2, 6-27-1989)
4-3-2: APPROVAL; FEE:
Upon approval of the intended route by the Code Enforcement Officer, a fee of
ten dollars ($10.00) for each day or fraction thereof that it is intended that
the building shall occupy any such portion of any such public place, shall be
paid to the Clerk and the permit issued. Additional payment of twenty dollars
($20.00) for each day or fraction thereof over and above the time stated on the
permit during which any building shall occupy any such public place shall be
paid. (Ord. 89-2, 6-27-1989)
4-3-3: BOND:
Every person applying for a permit under this chapter shall submit with his
application a cash bond with a lawful corporate surety to be approved by the
Code Enforcement Officer, conditioned on his compliance with all the provisions
of this chapter, and agreeing to pay and holding the City harmless from any
claim which may be made against it by reason of the occupation of any street,
alley, sidewalk or other public place by the building or structure moved. (Ord.
89-2, 6-27-1989)
4-3-4: LIGHTS AND WARNINGS:
Whenever a street or alley is blocked by a house or structure which is being
moved, warnings to that effect shall be placed, as may be directed by the
Police Department, so as to warn vehicles and persons from entering that
portion of the street so blocked.
The persons moving any building through the streets shall keep warning signs
and lights on the building so as to guard against any person or vehicle from
colliding with it. (1979 Code)
4-3-5: WIRES, CUTTING:
Whenever it shall be necessary to interfere with wires or cables of a public
utility in moving a building, the terms of any special or franchise ordinance
governing shall apply and the bond therein specified shall be given. If no such
terms apply then the Mayor shall estimate the expense of fixing the wires and
the bond to be given to cover such expense. (1979 Code)
4-3-6: FIRE ALARM WIRES:
When any moving building shall approach any fire alarm wire or pole, which
shall be endangered by the removal of such building or structure, it shall be
the duty of the mover to notify the Fire Chief at least six (6) hours before
reaching such wire or pole so that they may be removed or cared for by the City
authorities. (1979 Code)
4-3-7: DAMAGE TO CITY PROPERTY:
Any persons moving any buildings through the streets of the City shall be
liable to the City for any damage caused to the streets, sidewalks, City
utilities or other City property caused thereby. (1979 Code)
CHAPTER 4
FLOOD DAMAGE PREVENTION
SECTION:
4-4-1: Purpose
4-4-2: Definitions
4-4-3: Base Flood Elevation
4-4-4: Duties Of The City Code Enforcement Officer
4-4-5: Development Permit
4-4-6: Preventing Increased Flood Heights And Resulting Damages
4-4-7: Protecting Buildings
4-4-8: Subdivision Requirements
4-4-9: Public Health And Other Standards
4-4-10: Carrying Capacity And Notification
4-4-11: Variances
4-4-12: Disclaimer Of Liability
4-4-13: Penalty
4-4-14: Abrogation And Greater Restrictions
4-4-1: PURPOSE:
This chapter is enacted pursuant to the police powers granted to this City of
Carthage by the Illinois Municipal Code 1  in order to accomplish the following
purposes:
   (A)   To prevent unwise developments from increasing flood or drainage
hazards to others;
   (B)   To protect new buildings and major improvements to buildings from
flood damage;
   (C)   To promote and protect the public health, safety, and general welfare
of the citizens from the hazards of flooding;
   (D)   To lessen the burden on the taxpayer for flood control, repairs to
public facilities and utilities, and flood rescue and relief operations;
   (E)   To maintain property values and a stable tax base by minimizing the
potential for creating blight areas;
   (F)   To make Federally subsidized flood insurance available; and
   (G)   To preserve the natural characteristics and functions of watercourses
and floodplains in order to moderate flood and stormwater impacts, improve
water quality, reduce soil erosion, protect aquatic and riparian habitat,
provide recreational opportunities, provide aesthetic benefits and enhance
community and economic development. (Ord. 2009-15, 9-22-2009)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1, 5/11-12-12, 5/11-30-2, 5/11-30-8 and 5/11-31-2.
4-4-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions are adopted:
