peace of the City or the protection of persons or property. The policemen so
appointed shall be reported by the Mayor to the City Council at its next
meeting for confirmation by them. The Mayor or Council shall have the right to
revoke the appointment for any policemen as appointed as aforesaid with or
without cause, whenever in his or their judgment the same are not necessary.
The policemen shall be commissioned by the Mayor and attested by the Clerk
under the Seal of the City and such policemen when appointed shall possess the
powers of regular policemen in the City. (Ord. 90-14, 4-30-1991)
6-1-3: SUPERVISE, CONTROL POLICE:
The Mayor or such committee as he shall appoint from time to time, shall have
the general supervision and control of the police, and may make such rules and
regulations as to their duties as will promote the interest of the City,
preserve the laws and enforce the provisions of this Code. He shall see that
they discharge their duties and for any refusal or neglect of duty, drunkenness
or improper conduct may discharge any and all policemen and appoint others in
their place. (Ord. 9, 12-5-1908)
6-1-4: QUALIFICATION; BOND:
No person shall be appointed as a policeman who is under the age of twenty one
(21) years or who is interested or employed in the keeping of any coffee house,
restaurant, beer saloon or grocery for selling liquors. Every person so
appointed shall take and subscribe an oath or affirmation that he will, during
his continuance in office, well and truly discharge the duties thereof
according to law and the provisions of this Code, without favor or partiality.
The Mayor or Council may, if deemed best, require bond with security in the sum
of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) each, conditioned for the proper and
faithful discharge of their duties. (Ord. 9, 12-5-1908; amd. 2018 Code)
6-1-5: MALFEASANCE IN OFFICE:
The policemen shall obey all rules and regulations made by the Mayor or any
committee so designated by him, and for any neglect or failure to obey the same
or any call or orders of the Mayor or Chief of Police as their next superior
officer, or for any other neglect of duty or misfeasance or malfeasance in
office, shall, on conviction thereof be fined in a sum not to exceed five
hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 9, 12-5-1908; amd. 1979 Code)
6-1-6: DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of each member of the police to see to the enforcement of
all provisions of this Code and all statutes effective in the City, and to
preserve order and prevent infractions of the law and arrest violators thereof.
(Ord. 9, 12-5-1908; amd. 1979 Code)
6-1-7: CONFINEMENT, ARREST:
When any arrest is made in the night, or at any other time when the proper
court is not in session, or on Sunday, the officer shall convey the party
arrested to the County Jail or other place of confinement until the time for
the hearing of the case, unless bail is given as hereinafter provided. (Ord. 9,
12-5-1908; amd. 1979 Code)
6-1-8: USE OF COUNTY JAIL:
Until such time as the City shall procure a prison of its own, the County Jail
of Hancock County, Illinois, shall be used for the safe keeping of all persons
under arrest. (Ord. 9, 12-5-1908; amd. 1979 Code; 2018 Code)
6-1-9: PART-TIME POLICE:
   (A)   Employment: The City of Carthage may employ part-time police officers
from time to time as they deem necessary.
   (B)   Duties: A part-time police officer shall have all the responsibilities
of a full-time police officer and such specific duties as delineated in the
Policy Manual of the Carthage Police Department, but the number of hours a
part-time officer may work within a calendar year is restricted. Part-time
officers shall not be assigned to supervise or direct full-time police
officers. Part-time officers shall be trained in accordance with the Illinois
Police Training Act 1  and the rules and requirements of the ILETSB.
   (C)   Hiring Standards: Any person employed as a part-time officer must meet
the following standards:
      1.   Be of good moral character, of temperate habits, of sound health and
physically and mentally able to perform assigned duties.
      2.   Be at least twenty one (21) years of age.
      3.   Pass a medical examination.
      4.   Possess a high school diploma or GED certificate.
      5.   Possess a valid State of Illinois driver's license.
      6.   Possess no prior felony convictions.
      7.   Any individual who has served in the U.S. military must have been
honorably discharged.
   (D)   Discipline: Part-time officers shall be under the disciplinary
jurisdiction of the Chief of Police. Part-time officers serve at the direction
of the City of Carthage authorities, shall not have any property rights in said
employment, and may be removed by the City of Carthage authorities at any time.
Part-time police officers shall comply with all applicable rules and policies
issued by the Carthage Police Department. (Ord. 2011-15, 2-28-2012)
 
Notes
1 1. 50 ILCS 705/1 et seq.
CHAPTER 2
GENERAL OFFENSES
SECTION:
6-2-1: Penalty
6-2-2: Aiding, Abetting An Offense
6-2-3: Airguns
6-2-4: Assault And Battery
6-2-5: Breaking Street Lamps
6-2-6: Discharging Firearms
6-2-7: Disorderly Conduct
6-2-8: Disturbing Congregations Or Assemblies
6-2-9: Disturbing Funeral Assembly Or Procession
6-2-10: Disturbing The Peace; Animals
6-2-11: Drunkenness
6-2-12: Exhibitions; Incite Violence
6-2-13: False Weights And Measures
6-2-14: Fighting
6-2-15: Fireworks
6-2-16: Gambling
6-2-17: Handbills, Distribution Of
6-2-18: Indecent Writing In Public Places
6-2-19: Injuring Property
6-2-20: Junk Yards Prohibited
6-2-21: Keeping A Place Of Prostitution
6-2-22: Trespass
6-2-23: Officer, Impersonating
6-2-24: Officer, Refusing To Assist
6-2-25: Prostitution
6-2-26: Public Indecency
6-2-27: Throwing Missiles
6-2-28: Unlawful Assemblies
6-2-1: PENALTY:
Each of the following sections from
 6-2-1 to
6-2-28 inclusive, of this chapter shall be deemed to state a misdemeanor or
misdemeanors, which if severally or jointly committed by any person or persons
or corporation within the territorial jurisdiction of the City shall subject
the offender or offenders severally to a penalty upon conviction, of not less
than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00)
for each offense; provided, that, when more than one offense is stated in a
section the offender thereof shall be liable to only one penalty. (1979 Code;
amd. 2018 Code)
6-2-2: AIDING, ABETTING AN OFFENSE:
Any person who shall, directly or indirectly, knowingly aid, abet, assist,
advise, encourage or procure any person to commit any violation of any
provisions of this Code, shall be deemed a principal in the same manner as if
he had committed the offense, and shall be punished by the same fine as the
principal offender. (Ord. 13, 12-5-1908)
6-2-3: AIRGUNS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to carry or transport any BB gun, air
rifle, air gun, pellet gun or gas gun upon public property within the City,
unless said rifle or gun is carried unloaded in the case; and no persons will
discharge any BB gun, air rifle, air gun, pellet gun or gas gun upon public
property within the City limits of the City. (1979 Code)
6-2-4: ASSAULT AND BATTERY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to be guilty of any assault or of an
assault and battery. (Ord. 13, 12-5-1908)
6-2-5: BREAKING STREET LAMPS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any rifle or other firearm, or
any air gun, or to hurl any ball or missile by sling shot or otherwise at any
street lamp or street hood; or to carelessly or maliciously break, deface or in
any way injure or destroy any street lamp or street hood. (Ord. 159, 1-10-1910)
6-2-6: DISCHARGING FIREARMS:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any cannon, rifle,
musket, shotgun, pistol or other firearms, except in case of urgent necessity,
or except by the permission of the City police. (Ord. 13, 12-5-1908; amd. 2018
Code)
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to fire or discharge any rifle,
pistol or other firearms of like character upon, over or adjacent to the body
of water known as the Carthage Lake or the reservoir supplying the water to the
City.
It shall be unlawful for any person to fire or discharge any musket, shotgun or
similar firearms upon, over or across Carthage Lake or the territory adjacent
thereto or any other City property, except by permission of the City
Superintendent of the Waterworks of the City. (Ord. 447, 10-3-1938)
6-2-7: DISORDERLY CONDUCT:
It shall be unlawful for any person to be guilty of any disorderly conduct. A
person commits disorderly conduct when he knowingly:
   (A)   Does any act in such unreasonable manner as to alarm or disturb
another and to provoke a breach of the peace; or
   (B)   With intent to annoy another makes a telephone call whether or not
conversation thereby ensues; or
   (C)   Transmits in any manner to the Fire Department of any city, town or
village a false alarm of fire, knowing at the time of such transmission that
there is no reasonable ground for believing that such fire exists; or
   (D)   Transmits in any manner to another a false alarm to the effect that a
bomb or other explosive of any nature is concealed in such place that its
explosion would endanger human life, knowing that at the time of such
transmission that there is no reasonable grounds for believing that such a bomb
or explosion is concealed in such a place; or
   (E)   Transmits in any manner to any peace officer, public official or
public employee a report to the effect that an offense has been committed,
knowing at the time of such transmission that there is no reasonable ground for
believing that such an offense has been committed; or
   (F)   Enters upon the property of another and for a lewd or unlawful purpose
deliberately looks into a dwelling on the property through any window or other
opening in it; or
   (G)   While acting as a collection agency as defined in the "Collection
Agency Act" of the Illinois Compiled Statutes, or as an employee of such
collection agency, and while attempting to collect an alleged debt, makes a
telephone call to the alleged debtor which is designed to harass, annoy or
intimidate the alleged debtor. (1979 Code)
6-2-8: DISTURBING CONGREGATIONS OR ASSEMBLIES:
It shall be unlawful for any person in the City to interrupt or disturb any
congregation or assembly meant for the purpose of religious worship or for any
lawful purpose, by making any loud or unusual noise or by rude or indecent
behavior or by profane, obscene or improper discourse or conduct. (1979 Code)
6-2-9: DISTURBING FUNERAL ASSEMBLY OR PROCESSION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully interrupt or disturb any
funeral assembly or funeral procession. (1979 Code)
6-2-10: DISTURBING THE PEACE; ANIMALS:
It shall be unlawful for any person in the City to keep any dog, whelp, bitch,
calf or other animal shut up or tied up in any yard, house or other place which
by barking, howling or by other noises, shall disturb the peace and quiet of
any family, individual or neighborhood. (1979 Code)
6-2-11: DRUNKENNESS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to be found in the City in a state of
intoxication. (Ord. 14, 12-5-1908)
6-2-12: EXHIBITIONS; INCITE VIOLENCE:
It shall be unlawful and be deemed a nuisance for any person, within the City,
to engage in or cause or permit the showing, exhibition or exposure or
representation, either by picture or act or otherwise in any way, of any prize
fight or other fight, or combat between persons or between any person and an
animal, or of a sparring or boxing match of a bull, fowl or animal contest or
fight, or of a train or other robbery either of person, house or otherwise, or
of a murderous attack or assault, or of any scene or representation which may
or shall have a tendency to excite race hatred, or which may or has a tendency
to inculcate, expose or exhibit immorality or vice, or which in anywise may be
offensive to the public peace or decency or against good order or morals. (Ord.
161, 8-8-1910)
6-2-13: FALSE WEIGHTS AND MEASURES:
It shall be unlawful for any person within the City to sell or dispose of false
weights or measures, any goods, groceries, grain, fruit or other article. Any
person having charge of any scales who shall wilfully or through negligence and
carelessness, give a false weight of anything weighed by him on such scales
shall be deemed guilty of maintaining a nuisance and subject to penalty. (Ord.
13. 12-5-1908)
6-2-14: FIGHTING:
It shall be unlawful for two (2) or more persons, voluntarily or by agreement,
to engage in any fight or to use any blows or violence toward each other in any
angry or quarrelsome manner. (Ord. 13, 12-5-1908)
6-2-15: FIREWORKS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to set off or discharge any cracker,
torpedo, rocket, squib or other fireworks without the permission of the City
Mayor/police/Fire Chief. (Ord. 13, 12-5-1908; amd. 2018 Code)
6-2-16: GAMBLING:
   (A)   Gambling Houses: It shall be unlawful for any person to keep a house,
shop or place resorted to for the purpose of gambling, or to permit any person
in any house, room, shop or other place under his control or care to play
cards, dice, faro, roulette or other game for money, drink or thing. (Ord. 14,
12-5-1908)
6-2-17: HANDBILLS, DISTRIBUTION OF:
No person shall attach to or shall cause to be attached to the outside of any
motor vehicle in the City any handbill or handbills. (Ord. 740, 5-4-1964)
6-2-18: INDECENT WRITING IN PUBLIC PLACES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to write, draw, cut or make any indecent or
lewd word, object, sentence, phrase, design or figure in any public place or in
any place open to the public view within the City. (1979 Code)
6-2-19: INJURING PROPERTY 1 :
   (A)   Personal Property: It shall be unlawful for any person wilfully,
maliciously or for mischief to break, destroy, injure, disfigure or deface any
window, door or any part of any dwelling, house or other building not his own
or to in like manner attempt to break, destroy, injure or deface any such
building or part thereof by force such as throwing stones or other substances;
or to, in any manner, pull down, remove, destroy, injure, or disfigure any
sign, signpost, gate, gatepost, fence or railing, or any pile of wood, lumber
or other property of another; or to remove, overturn or injure any automobile
or other vehicle belonging to another, or to run off any domestic animal of
another.
   (B)   Trees, Shrubs: It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully,
maliciously or for mischief enter any orchard, yard, garden or enclosure of
another and mutilate, injure or destroy any tree, shrub, vine, fruit or
vegetable therein or take or carry away any fruit, vegetable or flower
therefrom without the consent of the owner or person in charge of the same.
   (C)   Burial Grounds: It shall be unlawful for any person to injure or
destroy, disfigure or deface any fence, railing or gate around any cemetery or
burying ground within the City, or which may be used as burying ground by the
inhabitants of the City without the corporate limits, or to destroy, injure,
disfigure or deface in any such cemetery or burying ground; or to turn or let
any animal or animals into any such cemetery or burying ground; or to leave any
gate or passage into such grounds open so that animals can go therein.
   (D)   Tombstones, Monuments: It shall be unlawful for any person to
mischievously write or mark or paint any words, letters, characters, pictures
or figures of any kind upon any fence, railing, gate or enclosure or open any
tombstone or monuments, or to commit any other nuisance in or about any such
cemetery or burying ground. (Ord. 13, 12-5-1908)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection
  8-1-3(G) of this Code.
6-2-20: JUNK YARDS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or operate what is commonly
known as a junk yard in the City. (Ord. 468, 8-5-1940)
6-2-21: KEEPING A PLACE OF PROSTITUTION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep a place of prostitution. Any person
who has or exercises control over the use of any place which could offer
seclusion or shelter for the practice of prostitution, who performs any of the
following acts, keeps a place of prostitution:
   (A)   Knowingly grants or permits the use: of such place for the purpose of
prostitution; or
   (B)   Grants or permits the use of such place under circumstances from which
he could reasonably know that the place is used or is to be used for purposes
of prostitution; or
   (C)   Permits the continued use of a place after becoming aware of facts or
circumstances from which he should reasonably know that the place is being used
for the purposes of prostitution. (1979 Code)
6-2-22: TRESPASS:
It shall be unlawful for any person in the City to trespass upon any place of
amusement, park, hotel or other business place, or private premises, or any
other place within the City, and to refuse to disperse or vacate such place
when requested to do so by any person in possession of any portion of the
premises who is annoyed or aggrieved thereby, or by any police officer. (1979
Code; amd. 2018 Code)
6-2-23: OFFICER, IMPERSONATING:
No person shall, in the City, falsely represent himself to be an officer of the
City, or shall, without being duly authorized by the City, exercise or attempt
to exercise any of the duties, functions or powers of a City officer, or shall
hinder, obstruct, resist or otherwise interfere with any City officer in the
discharge of his official duties, or attempt to prevent any such officer from
arresting any person, or attempt to rescue from such officer any person in his
custody. (Ord. 10, 12-5-1908)
6-2-24: OFFICER, REFUSING TO ASSIST:
It shall be unlawful for any person, whoever upon command refuses or knowingly
fails reasonably to aid a person known by him to be a peace officer in:
   (A)   Apprehending a person whom the officer is authorized to apprehend; or
   (B)   Preventing the commission, by another, of any offense. (1979 Code)
6-2-25: PROSTITUTION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to commit an act of prostitution. Any
person who performs, offers or agrees to perform any of the following acts for
money commits an act of prostitution:
   (A)   Any act of sexual intercourse; or
   (B)   Any act of deviate sexual conduct. (1979 Code)
6-2-26: PUBLIC INDECENCY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to be guilty of public indecency. A person
who performs any of the following acts in a public place commits a public
indecency. (1979 Code; amd. 2018 Code)
   (A)   An act of sexual intercourse; or
   (B)   An act of deviate sexual conduct; or
   (C)   A lewd exposure of the body done with the intent to arouse or to
satisfy the sexual desires of the person; or
   (D)   A lewd fondling or caress of the body of another of either sex.
A public place for the purposes of this section shall mean any place where the
conduct may reasonably be expected to be viewed by others. (1979 Code)
6-2-27: THROWING MISSILES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or cast any stone or other missile
upon or at any building, tree or other public or private property, or upon or
at any person in any street, avenue, alley, lane, public place or enclosed or
unenclosed ground in the City, or to aid or abet the same. (Ord. 13, 12-5-1908)
6-2-28: UNLAWFUL ASSEMBLIES:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any two (2) or more persons within the City,
to assemble together for any unlawful purpose, or who, being assembled to act
and concert to do an unlawful act, with force and violence against the property
of the City or the person or property of another, or against the peace or to
the terror of citizens or other persons or to make any movement or preparation
therefor.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to suffer or permit any
assembly for the purpose of committing any unlawful act or breach of peace, or
any riotous, offensive or disorderly conduct, in or upon premises owned or
occupied by him, or under his control within the City. (1979 Code)
CHAPTER 3
ANIMALS
SECTION:
6-3-1: Definition
6-3-2: Tags
6-3-3: Running At Large
6-3-4: Inoculation
6-3-5: Dog Bites
6-3-6: Impounding
6-3-7: Noise
6-3-8: Parents' Responsibility
6-3-9: Penalty
6-3-1: DEFINITION:
   DOG: Includes any canine. (Ord. 2015-3, 9-22-2015)
6-3-2: TAGS:
It shall be unlawful to permit any dog to be on any public street, sidewalk,
alley or other public place unless such dog has a collar firmly attached around
its neck with an inoculation tag for the current year attached to such collar.
(Ord. 2015-3, 9-22-2015)
6-3-3: RUNNING AT LARGE:
It shall be unlawful for any person who owns, harbors or keeps dogs to permit
such dogs to run at large within the Municipality. Any dog found upon any
public street, sidewalk, alley, parkway or any unenclosed place (other than the
premises or yard owned or rented by the owner of the dog or owned or rented by
a member of the family of the owner of the dog) shall be deemed as running at
large unless such dog is firmly held on a leash or is in an enclosed vehicle.
(Ord. 2015-3, 9-22-2015)
6-3-4: INOCULATION:
All dogs three (3) months or more of age must be inoculated against rabies by a
licensed veterinarian within the preceding year. (Ord. 2015-3, 9-22-2015)
6-3-5: DOG BITES:
It shall be the duty of the owner or person having custody of any dog which
bites any human being to keep such dog locked up in an enclosure for a period
of ten (10) days following the time the dog has bitten the person and to have
the dog examined by a physician or licensed veterinarian at the commencement
and termination of this ten (10) day period. If such dog, during this period,
shall die or shall show definite signs of illness, it shall be the duty of such
owner or person having custody of the dog to turn the dog over to the County
animal control warden so that it can be determined whether or not the dog had
rabies. (Ord. 2015-3, 9-22-2015; amd. 2018 Code)
6-3-6: IMPOUNDING:
Any dog found upon a public street or highway running at large shall be
impounded by the County animal control warden. Any dog not having been redeemed
within seven (7) business days after being impounded shall be disposed of in
the manner prescribed by the City Council. Any dog impounded may be redeemed by
the owner upon payment of a fee of five dollars ($5.00) per day for each day
the dog is impounded. Such fees shall be paid to the City Collector. (Ord.
2015-3, 9-22-2015; amd. 2018 Code)
6-3-7: NOISE:
All persons owning, possessing or harboring a dog shall prevent such dog from
barking or making other sounds common to its species in an excessive,
continuous or untimely fashion. Thirty (30) minutes or more is deemed
excessive. Any barking between ten thirty o'clock (10:30) P.M. and five o'clock
(5:00) A.M. is considered untimely and is a violation, whether or not it
persists thirty (30) minutes. (Ord. 2015-3, 9-22-2015)
6-3-8: PARENTS' RESPONSIBILITY:
The parent or guardian of any minor claiming ownership of any dog shall be
deemed to be the owner of such animal and shall be charged for all penalties
and fees imposed by this chapter. (Ord. 2015-3, 9-22-2015)
6-3-9: PENALTY:
Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be fined a minimum of
seventy five dollars ($75.00) but not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00)
for the first offense; a minimum of one hundred twenty five dollars ($125.00)
but not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the second offense; a
minimum of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) but not more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) for the third offense and a minimum of one hundred seventy
five dollars ($175.00) but not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for
each additional offense per twelve (12) month period. (Ord. 2015-3, 9-22-2015)
CHAPTER 3A
DANGEROUS DOGS
SECTION:
6-3A-1: Purpose And Intent
6-3A-2: Definitions
6-3A-3: Liability Insurance Or Other Evidence Of Financial Responsibility
Required
6-3A-4: Confinement Of Dangerous Dogs
6-3A-5: Registration Of Dangerous Dogs
6-3A-6: Enforcement
6-3A-7: Notice Of Keeping Of Dangerous Dog
6-3A-8: Severability
6-3A-9: Nuisance, Injunction
6-3A-10: Penalties
6-3A-1: PURPOSE AND INTENT:
The purpose of this chapter is to promote the public health, safety and general
welfare of the citizens of the City of Carthage. It is intended to be
applicable to dangerous dogs as defined herein, and to regulate dangerous dogs,
by ensuring responsible handling by their owners through environment and
liability insurance. (Ord. 2015-3, 9-22-2015)
6-3A-2: DEFINITIONS:
   DANGEROUS DOG: Any dog that, because of its aggressive nature, training or
characteristic behavior, presents a risk of serious physical harm or death to
human beings, or would constitute a danger to human life, physical well being,
or property if not kept under direct control of the owner. This definition
shall not apply to dogs utilized by law enforcement officers in the performance
of their duties. The term "dangerous dog" includes any dog that according to
the records of either the City of Carthage or any other law enforcement agency:
   (A)   Has aggressively bitten, attacked, endangered, or inflicted severe
injury on a human being on public or private property, or when unprovoked, has
chased or approached a person upon the street, sidewalks, or any public grounds
in a menacing fashion or an apparent attitude of attack, provided that such
actions are attested to in a sworn statement by one or more persons and
dutifully investigated by any of the above referenced authorities;
   (B)   Has more than once severely injured or killed a domestic animal while
off the owner's property; or
   (C)   Has been used primarily or in part for the purpose of dogfighting, or
is a dog trained for dogfighting.
   IMPOUNDMENT: The taking or picking up and confining of an animal by any
police officer, animal control officer, or other public officer under the
provisions of this chapter.
   MUZZLE: A device constructed of strong, soft material or of metal, designed
to fasten over the mouth of an animal to prevent the animal from biting any
person or other animal.
   OWNER: Any person, partnership, corporation or other legal entity owning,
harboring or keeping any animal, or in the case of a person under the age of
eighteen (18), that person's parent or legal guardian. An animal shall be
deemed to be harbored if it is fed or sheltered for three (3) or more
consecutive days. This definition shall not apply to any veterinary clinic or
boarding kennel.
   SANITARY CONDITION: A condition of good order and cleanliness to minimize
the possibility of disease transmission.
   UNDER RESTRAINT: An animal is secured by a leash, led under the control of a
person physically capable of restraining the animal or obedient to that
person's commands, or securely enclosed within the real property limits of the
owner's premises. (Ord. 2015-3, 9-22-2015)
6-3A-3: LIABILITY INSURANCE OR OTHER EVIDENCE OF FINANCIAL RESPONSIBILITY
REQUIRED:
In order to protect the public and to afford relief from the severe harm and
injury which is likely to result from a dangerous animal or dog attack, every
owner of a dangerous animal or dog shall at all times provide evidence of
financial responsibility and the ability to respond in damages to and include
the amount of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for bodily injury to
or death of any person or persons or for damage to property owned by persons
which may result from the ownership, keeping or maintenance of such animal or
dog. Proof of the ability to respond in damages shall be given by filing with
the City Clerk of the City of Carthage a certificate of insurance from an
insurance company authorized to do business in the State stating that the owner
is and will be insured against liability to respond to such damages, or by
posting with the City Clerk of the City of Carthage a surety bond conditioned
upon payment of such damages during the period of such registration or other
equivalent evidence of financial responsibility, such as a personal bond
secured by a mortgage in real estate or security interest in personal property.
(Ord. 2015-3, 9-22-2015)
6-3A-4: CONFINEMENT OF DANGEROUS DOGS:
   (A)   Dangerous dogs must at all times be securely confined indoors, or
confined in a securely and totally enclosed and locked pen, with either a top
or sides at least six feet (6') in height and a wall to wall concrete slab
floor.
   (B)   At any time that a dangerous dog is not confined as required in
subsection (A) of this section, the dog shall be muzzled in such a manner as to
prevent it from biting or injuring any person or animal, and kept on a leash
with the owner or custodian in attendance.
   (C)   An exception to this section is provided for any dangerous dog in
attendance of, or participating in, any lawful dog show, contest or exhibition
sponsored by a dog club, association, society or similar organization.
   (D)   An exception to this section is provided for any dangerous dog when
the dog is actually engaged in the sport of hunting in authorized areas and
supervised by a competent person. (Ord. 2015-3, 9-22-2015)
6-3A-5: REGISTRATION OF DANGEROUS DOGS:
   (A)   In order to assure that owners of dangerous dogs are in compliance
with the requirements of this chapter, and to assist in assuring compliance,
every owner of a dangerous dog in the City of Carthage shall register the dog
with the City Clerk of the City of Carthage. The registration shall include the
following:
Name, address and telephone number of the dog's owner; the address where the
dog is harbored, if different from the owner's address; a complete
identification of the dog including the dog's sex, color, and any other
distinguishing physical characteristics; proof of rabies vaccination; and proof
of the liability insurance or other evidence of financial responsibility
required pursuant to this chapter.
   (B)   Newly acquired dangerous dogs shall be registered with the City Clerk
of the City of Carthage and the City's designated animal control officer no
later than seventy two (72) hours of acquisition.
   (C)   Every owner, upon receipt of a dangerous dog notice, shall register
the animal with the City Clerk within seventy two (72) hours of receipt of the
dangerous dog notice. (Ord. 2015-3, 9-22-2015)
6-3A-6: ENFORCEMENT:
It shall be the duty and responsibility of all the City of Carthage law
enforcement officers and the designated animal control officer to enforce the
provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 2015-3, 9-22-2015)
6-3A-7: NOTICE OF KEEPING OF DANGEROUS DOG:
Upon written complaint of any person that a person owns or is keeping or
harboring a dangerous dog on premises in the City of Carthage, the animal
control officer may cause the matter to be investigated and if after
investigation, the facts indicate that such person, named in the complaint, is
in fact the owner or is keeping any dangerous dog in the City of Carthage and
has not registered under this chapter, he shall send written notice to such
person, requiring such person to either apply for a registration under this
chapter or remove the animal from the City limits of the City of Carthage
within three (3) days of the date of the notice. (Ord. 2015-3, 9-22-2015)
6-3A-8: SEVERABILITY:
The provisions of this chapter are severable. If any provision of this chapter
or its application to any person or circumstance is held invalid, such
invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applications of this chapter
which can be given effect without the invalid provisions or application. (Ord.
2015-3, 9-22-2015)
6-3A-9: NUISANCE, INJUNCTION:
Any violation of this chapter is declared to be a nuisance. In addition to any
other relief provided by this chapter, the City Attorney may apply to a court
of competent jurisdiction for an injunction to prohibit the continuation of any
violation of this chapter. Such application for relief may include seeking a
temporary restraining order, temporary injunction and permanent injunction.
(Ord. 2015-3, 9-22-2015)
6-3A-10: PENALTIES:
   (A)   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall, upon
conviction, be punished by a fine not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00)
nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). This chapter shall not be deemed
to be violated unless the alleged violator knew, or should have known after a
reasonable inquiry, that the dog which is the subject of the alleged violation
is a dangerous dog under the provisions of this title.
   (B)   Any owner who fails to register the dangerous dog with the City Clerk
within the required three (3) days will result in the dangerous dog being
impounded by animal control. (Ord. 2015-3, 9-22-2015)
CHAPTER 3B
ANIMAL NUISANCES
SECTION:
6-3B-1: Nuisance Declared
6-3B-2: Violation; Penalty
6-3B-1: NUISANCE DECLARED:
It is hereby declared to be a nuisance and a danger to the health, safety,
welfare, peace and comfort of the City of Carthage and its residents for any
person to:
   (A)   Animals: To keep or suffer to be kept upon or about his premises or
upon vacant property or public streets or public property within the City any
goat, sheep, hog, cattle, fowl or other animal, reptile or serpent other than
domesticated house pets; or
   (B)   Animal Carcasses: To cause or permit to be collected or to remain upon
any premises or place any animal carcass, or any offal, filth, excretion or
other noisome or noxious animal matter of any kind which is, or is likely to
become, putrid, foul or offensive; or
   (C)   Stables And Pigsties: To locate or maintain, or permit to exist or
remain, anywhere within the City any stable or pigsty. (Ord. 2015-3, 9-22-2015)
6-3B-2: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be fined a minimum of
seventy five dollars ($75.00) but not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00).
(Ord. 2015-3, 9-22-2015)
CHAPTER 4
ABANDONED VEHICLES
SECTION:
6-4-1: Definitions
6-4-2: Removal Of Abandoned Vehicle
6-4-3: Towing Service, Maintain Records
6-4-4: Authorize Removal
6-4-5: Police Department, Maintain Records
6-4-6: Owner Unknown
6-4-7: Notify State Police, Identify Owner
6-4-8: Proof Of Ownership
6-4-9: Notice Of Sale Of Vehicle
6-4-10: Registered Owner Undetermined
6-4-11: Disposal Of Vehicle, Maintain Report
6-4-12: Proceeds Of Sale
6-4-13: Liability For Damages
6-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings
ascribed to them as follows:
   ABANDONED VEHICLE: All motor vehicles or other vehicles in a state of
disrepair rendering the vehicle incapable of being driven in its condition; or
any motor vehicle or other vehicle that has not been moved or used for seven
(7) consecutive days or more and is apparently deserted.
   ANTIQUE VEHICLE: A motor vehicle that is more than twenty five (25) years
old or a bona fide replica thereof and which is driven on the highway only
going to and returning from an antique auto show or an exhibition, or for
servicing or demonstration, or a firefighting vehicle more than twenty (20)
years old which is not used as firefighting equipment but is used only for the
purpose of exhibition or demonstration.
   HIGHWAY: Any street, alley or public way within the City. (Ord. 70-5, 7-6-
1970; amd. Ord. 95-3, 5-23-1995)
6-4-2: REMOVAL OF ABANDONED VEHICLE:
The abandonment of a motor vehicle or other vehicle or any part thereof on any
highway in the Municipality is unlawful and subject to penalties as set forth
herein. The abandonment of a motor vehicle or other vehicle or any part thereof
on private or public property, other than a highway, in view of the general
public, anywhere in the Municipality is unlawful except on property of the
owner or bailee of such abandoned vehicle. A motor vehicle or other vehicle or
any part thereof so abandoned on private property may be authorized for removal
by or upon the order of the Chief of Police of the Municipality, after a
waiting period of seven (7) days or more has expired. (Ord. 70-5, 7-6-1970)
6-4-3: TOWING SERVICE, MAINTAIN RECORDS:
When an abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed motor vehicle or other vehicle
comes into the temporary possession or custody of a person in this State, not
the owner of the vehicle, such person shall immediately notify the Municipal
Police Department when the vehicle is within the corporate limits of the City.
Upon receipt of such notification, the Chief of the Police Department shall
authorize a towing service to remove and take possession of the abandoned,
lost, stolen or unclaimed motor vehicle or other vehicle. The towing service
will safely keep the towed vehicle and its contents, maintain a record of the
tow until the vehicle is claimed by the owner or any other person legally
entitled to possession thereof, or until it is disposed of as provided in this
chapter. (Ord. 70-5, 7-6-1970)
6-4-4: AUTHORIZE REMOVAL:
   (A)   When a motor vehicle or other vehicle is abandoned on a highway in the
City ten (10) hours or more, its removal by a towing service may be authorized
by order of the Chief of Police of the City.
   (B)   When an abandoned, unattended, wrecked, burned or partially dismantled
motor vehicle or other vehicle is creating a traffic hazard because of its
position in relation to the highway or its physical appearance is causing the
impeding of traffic, its immediate removal from the highway by a towing service
may be authorized by order of the Chief of Police of the City.
   (C)   When a vehicle removed from either public or private property is
authorized by order of the Chief of Police, the owner of the vehicle will be
responsible for all towing costs. (Ord. 70-5, 7-6-1970)
6-4-5: POLICE DEPARTMENT, MAINTAIN RECORDS:
When a motor vehicle or other vehicle is authorized to be towed away, the
Police Department shall keep and maintain a record of the vehicle towed,
listing the color, year of manufacture, manufacturer's trade name,
manufacturer's series name, body style, vehicle identification number and
license plate year and number displayed on the vehicle. The record shall also
include the date and hour of tow, location towed from, location towed to,
reason for towing and the name of the officer authorizing the tow. (Ord. 70-5,
7-6-1970)
6-4-6: OWNER UNKNOWN:
When the Police Department does not know the identity of the registered owner
or other legally entitled person, they will cause the motor vehicle
registration records of the State of Illinois to be searched by a directed
communication to the Secretary of State for the purpose of obtaining the
required ownership information.
The Police Department will cause the stolen motor vehicle files of the Illinois
State Police to be searched by a directed communication to the Illinois State
Police for stolen or wanted information on the vehicle. When the Illinois State
Police files are searched with negative results, the information contained in
the National Crime Information Center (NCIC) files will be searched by the
Illinois State Police. The information determined from these record searches
will be used by the Police Department in sending a notification by certified
mail to the owner or legally entitled person advising where the vehicle is
held, requesting a disposition be made and setting forth public sale
information. (Ord. 70-5, 7-6-1970)
6-4-7: NOTIFY STATE POLICE, IDENTIFY OWNER:
When the registered owner or other person legally entitled to the possession of
a motor vehicle or other vehicle cannot be identified from the registration
files of this State or from the registration files of a foreign state, if
applicable, the Police Department shall notify the Illinois State Police for
the purpose of identifying the vehicle's owner or other person legally entitled
to the possession of the vehicle. The information obtained by the Illinois
State Police will be immediately forwarded to the law enforcement agency having
custody of the vehicle for notification of owner. (Ord. 70-5, 7-6-1970)
6-4-8: PROOF OF OWNERSHIP:
Any time before a motor vehicle or other vehicle is sold at public sale or
disposed of as provided herein, the owner or other person legally entitled to
its possession may reclaim the vehicle by presenting to the Police Department
proof of ownership or proof of the right to possession of the vehicle. No
vehicle shall be released to the owner or other person under this section until
all towing and storage charges have been paid. (Ord. 70-5, 7-6-1970)
6-4-9: NOTICE OF SALE OF VEHICLE:
Whenever an abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed motor vehicle or other
vehicle, seven (7) years of age or newer, remains unclaimed by the registered
owner or other person legally entitled to its possession for a period of thirty
(30) days after notice has been given as provided herein, the Police Department
having possession of the vehicle shall cause it to be sold at public sale to
the highest bidder. Notice of the time and place of the sale shall be posted in
a conspicuous place for at least ten (10) days prior to the sale on the
premises where the vehicle has been impounded. At least ten (10) days prior to
the sale, the Police Department shall cause a notice of the time and place of
the sale to be sent by certified mail to the registered owner or other person
known by the Police Department or towing service to be legally entitled to the
possession of the vehicle. Such notice shall contain a complete description of
the vehicle to be sold and what steps must be taken by any legally entitled
person to reclaim the vehicle.
In those instances where the certified notification specified herein has been
returned by the postal authorities to the Police Department due to the
addressee having moved, or being unknown at the address obtained from the
registration records of this State, the sending of a second certified notice
will not be required. (Ord. 70-5, 7-6-1970)
6-4-10: REGISTERED OWNER UNDETERMINED:
When the identity of the registered owner or other person legally entitled to
the possession of an abandoned, lost or unclaimed vehicle of seven (7) years of
age or newer cannot be determined by any means provided for in this chapter,
the vehicle may be sold as provided herein or disposed of in the manner
authorized by this chapter without notice to the registered owner or other
person legally entitled to the possession of the vehicle.
When an abandoned vehicle of more than seven (7) years of age is impounded as
specified by this chapter, it will be kept in custody for a minimum of ten (10)
days for the purpose of determining ownership, the contacting of the registered
owner by the U.S. mail, public service or in person for a determination of
disposition; and, an examination of the Illinois State Police stolen motor
vehicle files for theft and wanted information. At the expiration of the ten
(10) day period, without the benefit of disposition information being received
from the registered owner, the Chief of Police will authorize the disposal of
the vehicle as junk only.
A motor vehicle or other vehicle classified as an antique vehicle is excluded
from this chapter. (Ord. 70-5, 7-6-1970)
6-4-11: DISPOSAL OF VEHICLE, MAINTAIN REPORT:
When a motor vehicle or other vehicle in the custody of the Police Department
is reclaimed by the registered owner or other legally entitled person, or when
the vehicle is sold at public sale or otherwise disposed of as provided in this
chapter, a report of the transaction will be maintained by the Police
Department for a period of one year from the date of the sale or disposal.
(Ord. 70-5, 7-6-1970)
6-4-12: PROCEEDS OF SALE:
When a vehicle located within the corporate limits of the City is authorized to
be towed away by the Chief of Police and disposed of as set forth in this
chapter, the proceeds of the public sale or disposition after the deduction of
towing, storage and processing charges shall be deposited in the Municipal
Treasury. (Ord. 70-5, 7-6-1970)
6-4-13: LIABILITY FOR DAMAGES:
Any police officer, towing service, owner, operator or employee shall not be
held to answer or be liable for damages in any action brought by the registered
owner, former registered owner or his legal representative, or any other person
legally entitled to the possession of a motor vehicle or other vehicle when the
vehicle was processed and sold or disposed of as provided by this chapter.
(Ord. 70-5, 7-6-1970)
CHAPTER 5
GRASS/WEEDS 1
SECTION:
6-5-1: Definition
6-5-2: Height
6-5-3: Owner To Cut
6-5-4: Lien Against Property
6-5-5: Discarding Of Clippings
6-5-6: Fine
 
Notes
  1. See also sections
1 7-2-2-3 and
  7-3-4 of this Code.
6-5-1: DEFINITION:
"Weeds" as used in this chapter shall include the burdock, ragweed (giant),
ragweed (common), thistle, cocklebur, jimson, blue vervain, common milkweed,
wild carrot, poison ivy, wild mustard, rough pigweed, lambsquarter, wild
lettuce, curled dock, smart weeds (all varieties), poison hemlock, wild hemp
and other similar vegetation. (Ord. 2019-02, 7-9-2019)
6-5-2: HEIGHT:
It is hereby declared to be illegal for the owners of real estate to refuse or
neglect to cut grass or weeds when such grass or weeds shall have reached a
height in excess of six inches (6"). (Ord. 2019-02, 7-9-2019)
6-5-3: OWNER TO CUT:
Every real estate owner within the City shall cut grass or weeds on his/her
property at all such times as may be necessary so that such shall not exceed
six inches (6") in height, and if the owner neglects or refuses to cut grass or
weeds so that such grass or weeds shall exceed six inches (6") in height, the
City may cut the grass or weeds or authorize someone to cut the grass or weeds
on behalf of the City. (Ord. 2019-02, 7-9-2019)
6-5-4: LIEN AGAINST PROPERTY:
If grass or weeds are cut by the City or by someone directed to cut them on
behalf of the City, a notice of lien of the cost and expense thereof incurred
by the City shall be recorded in the following manner: The City Clerk or the
person performing the service by authority of the City, in its or his own name,
may file notice of lien in the Office of the Recorder of Deeds of Hancock
County. The notice of lien shall consist of a sworn statement setting out:
   (A)   A description of the real estate for identification thereof;
   (B)   The amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or
payable for the service; together with a weed lien fee of one hundred dollars
($100.00), payable to the City and notice that the lien shall draw interest at
the rate of five percent (5%); and
   (C)   The date or dates when said cost and expense was incurred by the City,
and shall be filed within sixty (60) days after the cost and expense is
incurred.
Upon payment of the fee, cost, interest and expense after notice of lien has
been filed, the lien shall be released by the City or person in whose name the
lien has been filed and the release shall be filed of record in the same manner
as filing notice of the said lien, upon payment of the recording fee by the
owner of the real estate. (Ord. 2019-02, 7-9-2019)
6-5-5: DISCARDING OF CLIPPINGS:
No person shall dump, deposit, drop, throw, discard, leave, cause or permit the
dumping, depositing, dropping, throwing, discarding or leaving of grass
clippings upon any public or private property in this City unless:
   (A)   The property has been designated by the State or any of its agencies,
political subdivisions, units of local government or school districts for the
disposal of litter, and the litter is disposed of on that property in
accordance with the applicable rules and regulations of the Pollution Control
Board;
   (B)   The litter is placed into a receptacle or other container intended by
the owner or tenant in lawful possession of that property for the deposit of
litter;
   (C)   The person is the owner or tenant in lawful possession of the property
or has first obtained the consent of the owner or tenant in lawful possession,
or unless the act is done under the person or direction of the owner or tenant
and does not create a public health or safety hazard, a public nuisance, or a
fire hazard. (Ord. 2019-02, 7-9-2019)
6-5-6: FINE:
The minimum fine for violation of this chapter shall be seventy five dollars
($75.00) with a maximum fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 2019-02,
7-9-2019)
CHAPTER 6
CURFEW
SECTION:
6-6-1: Age Limit; Hours
6-6-2: Parents' Responsibility
6-6-3: Detention By Police
6-6-4: Penalty
6-6-1: AGE LIMIT; HOURS:
It is unlawful for any person less than eighteen (18) years of age to be
present at or upon any public assembly, building, place, street or highway at
the following times unless accompanied by a parent, legal guardian or other
responsible companion of at least eighteen (18) years of age, approved by
parent or legal guardian or unless engaged in a business or occupation which
the laws of this State authorize a person less than eighteen (18) years of age
to perform: (Ord. 69-6, 6-2-1969; amd. 2018 Code)
Between 12:01 A.M. and 6:00 A.M. Saturday;
Between 12:01 A.M. and 6:00 A.M. Sunday; and
Between 11:00 P.M. on Sunday to Thursday inclusive and 6:00 A.M. on the
following day. (Ord. 69-6, 6-2-1969)
6-6-2: PARENTS' RESPONSIBILITY:
It shall be unlawful for a parent, legal guardian or other person to knowingly
permit a person in his custody or control to violate section
6-6-1 of this chapter. (Ord. 69-6, 6-2-1969)
6-6-3: DETENTION BY POLICE:
Each member of the police force is hereby authorized to detain any person
violating provisions of section
6-6-1 of this chapter until he is turned over to the custody of the parent,
guardian or other person having the care and custody of such child. (Ord. 69-6,
6-2-1969)
6-6-4: PENALTY:
A person convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter shall be
fined not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than one hundred
dollars ($100.00). (Ord. 69-6, 6-2-1969; amd. 2018 Code)
CHAPTER 7
CATS
SECTION:
6-7-1: Definition
6-7-2: Identification And Inoculation
6-7-3: Cats Running At Large Prohibited
6-7-4: Parents' Responsibility
6-7-5: Cat Bites
6-7-6: Impounding
6-7-7: Noise
6-7-8: Penalty
6-7-1: DEFINITION:
   CAT: Includes any cat. (Ord. 93-7, 8-10-1993)
6-7-2: IDENTIFICATION AND INOCULATION:
Every person residing in the City and owning or having in his possession any
cat shall have such cat bear some identification, either by tag, tattoo or
other suitable means of identification.
All cats three (3) months or more of age must be inoculated against rabies by a
licensed veterinarian within the preceding year. (Ord. 93-7, 8-10-1993)
6-7-3: CATS RUNNING AT LARGE PROHIBITED:
No person shall permit his cat to run at large within the limits of the City at
any time. A cat shall be deemed at large when off the premises of its owner or
keeper without being under adequate control of its owner or keeper. (Ord. 93-7,
8-10-1993)
6-7-4: PARENTS' RESPONSIBILITY:
The parent or guardian of any minor claiming ownership of any cat shall be
deemed to be the owner of such animal and shall be charged for all penalties
and fees imposed by this chapter. (Ord. 93-7, 8-10-1993)
6-7-5: CAT BITES:
It shall be the duty of the owner or person having custody of any cat which
bites any human being to keep such cat locked up in an enclosure for a period
of ten (10) days following the time the cat has bitten the person and to have
the cat examined by a physician or licensed veterinarian at the commencement
and termination of this ten (10) day period. If such cat, during this period,
shall die or shall show definite signs of illness, it shall be the duty of such
owner or person having custody of the cat to turn the cat over to the County
animal control warden so that it can be determined whether or not the cat had
rabies. (Ord. 93-7, 8-10-1993; amd. 2018 Code)
6-7-6: IMPOUNDING:
Any cat found upon a public street or highway running at large shall be
impounded by the appropriate veterinary service. Any cat not having been
redeemed within seven (7) days after being impounded shall be disposed of in
the manner prescribed by the City Council. (Ord. 93-7, 8-10-1993; amd. 2018
Code)
Any cat impounded may be redeemed by the owner upon payment of a fee of five
dollars ($5.00) per day for each day the cat is impounded. Such fees shall be
paid to the City Collector. (Ord. 93-7, 8-10-1993)
6-7-7: NOISE:
All persons owning, possessing or harboring a cat shall prevent such cat from
whining or making other sounds common to its species in an excessive,
continuous or untimely fashion. (Ord. 93-7, 8-10-1993)
6-7-8: PENALTY:
Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be fined a minimum of
seventy five dollars ($75.00) but not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00)
for the first offense; a minimum of one hundred twenty five dollars ($125.00)
but not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for second offense; a minimum
of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) but not more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) for third offense and a minimum of one hundred seventy five dollars
($175.00) but not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each additional
offense per twelve (12) month period. (Ord. 93-7, 8-10-1993; amd. 2018 Code)
CHAPTER 8
CANNABIS AND DRUG PARAPHERNALIA
SECTION:
6-8-1: Definitions
6-8-2: Possession Under Twenty One (21) Unlawful
6-8-3: Citations
6-8-4: Evidence Collection
6-8-5: Reports
6-8-6: Expungement And Sealing
6-8-7: Violation - Penalty
6-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
   CANNABIS: Cannabis includes marijuana, hashish, and other substances which
are identified as including any parts of the plant Cannabis Sativa, whether
growing or not; the seeds thereof, the resin extracted from any part of such
plant; and any compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixtures or preparation
of such plant, its seeds, or resin, including tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and
all other cannabinol derivatives, including its naturally occurring or
synthetically produced ingredients, whether produced directly or indirectly by
extraction, or independently by means of chemical synthesis or by a combination
of extraction and chemical synthesis; but shall not include the mature stalks
of such plant, fiber produced from such stalks, oil or cake made from the seeds
of such plant, and any compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture or
preparation of such mature stalks (except the resin extracted therefrom),
fiber, oil or cake, or the sterilized seed of such plant which is incapable of
germination.
   DRUG PARAPHERNALIA: Drug paraphernalia includes any paraphernalia to use in
ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing cannabis into the human body, or
in preparing cannabis for that use. (Ord. 2016-4, 11-8-2016)
6-8-2: POSSESSION UNDER TWENTY ONE (21) UNLAWFUL:
It is unlawful for any person under the age of twenty one (21) years to possess
any quantity of a substance containing cannabis. All violations under this
section are to be prosecuted as civil law violations and are not criminal. The
effect of this chapter shall be limited for purposes of municipal prosecution
and shall have no effect or application to any offense or violation under the
Illinois Criminal Code. Possession of any amount of cannabis pursuant to a duly
authorized medical possession is not a violation of this section. (Ord. 2019-
12, 2-25-2020)
6-8-3: CITATIONS:
   (A)   Citations: Officers will modify their Municipal Citation and Complaint
form, consistent with Supreme Court Rule 589, including providing the notices
required by Supreme Court Rule. Civil law citations in the Municipality may be
issued by the City police, the Illinois State Police, the County Sheriff or any
other Illinois law enforcement officer. The civil violation is a "must appear"
offense, unless:
      1.   The defendant admits to the violation and pays a fine of one hundred
dollars ($100.00) to the City Clerk or the Clerk's designee, at the Office of
the City Clerk, within fourteen (14) days from the date of the citation, or
unless
      2.   The defendant admits to the violation and pays one hundred twenty
dollars ($120.00) to the Circuit Clerk (which includes all fines, penalties and
costs) on or before the appearance date on the citation.
      3.   In the event the defendant fails to admit and pay the City Clerk as
provided in subsection (A)1 of this section, or in the alternative, fails to
admit and pay the Circuit Clerk as provided in subsection (A)2 of this section,
the defendant must appear in Circuit Court on the day provided in the citation.
   (B)   Separate Citations: A separate citation shall be issued for each
offense. Officers will:
      1.   Check "Notice to Appear" as the (only) form of bond (no cash bond);
      2.   Provide a court date that is between 14 - 60 days from the date of
the offense; and
      3.   Inform the violator that he/or she can satisfy the civil citation by
payment to the City Clerk as provided in subsection (A)1 of this section or by
payment to the Circuit Clerk as provided in subsection (A)2 of this section
prior to the appearance date, or by appearing on the court date provided; and
      4.   Complete the required stop cards for all enforcement stops of
citizens; and
      5.   Officers will not arrest and/or transport subjects to jail
exclusively for a civil citation and therefore will not make parental
notifications for juveniles. Citations written to juveniles are confidential
and should be handled in the same manner as other juvenile documents. (Ord.
2016-4, 11-8-2016)
6-8-4: EVIDENCE COLLECTION:
   (A)   The burden of proof to convict for a civil cannabis citation depends
upon the completion of a positive field test by a trained and experienced
police officer or based upon the training, experience, and observations of the
trained officer.
   (B)   Officers seizing cannabis should first weigh the cannabis to determine
if it is within the threshold qualifying for a "civil citation" (10 grams or
less).
   (C)   All other standard evidence processing procedures remain in effect.
(Ord. 2016-4, 11-8-2016)
6-8-5: REPORTS:
   (A)   Civil Citation: The "civil citation" will serve as the report.
Officers will insert the following verbiage on the lines provided for Nature of
Offense: "10.0 grams or less of a substance containing Cannabis - Field Test
Positive" or "Possession of Drug Paraphernalia with 10.0 grams or less
Cannabis".
   (B)   Notations: After giving the violator their respective copies of the
citation, officers will make very brief notations directly on the top copy of
the citation documenting their observations leading to the seizure of cannabis
or drug paraphernalia.
   (C)   Field Reports: Field reports will not be completed for civil
violations and will only be completed if an officer takes a subject into
custody for a criminal offense and a civil violation is the proximate cause for
the arrest.
   (D)   Evidence Inventory Form: An Evidence Inventory form, will be completed
in all instances where any amount of cannabis is seized and a copy will be
provided to the violator. On the face of the inventory form, the officer will
use the citation number for the report number and write "10.0 grams or less
Cannabis - Field Test Positive" or "Possession of Drug Paraphernalia with 10.0
grams or less Cannabis".
   (E)   Fingerprinting: Fingerprints will not be taken for "civil citations".
When a subject is taken into custody for a criminal offense, "civil citations"
written during the same encounter will not be documented on the fingerprint
report.
   (F)   Warning To Motorist: Officers will give subjects arrested for DUI
cannabis the standard warning to motorist. (Ord. 2016-4, 11-8-2016)
6-8-6: EXPUNGEMENT AND SEALING 1 :
Arrest and disposition records related to the newly created civil law
violations for the possession of cannabis and drug paraphernalia are required
to be automatically expunged on or before January 1 or July 1 of each year.
(Ord. 2016-4, 11-8-2016)
 
Notes
1 1. 20 ILCS 2630/5.2.
6-8-7: VIOLATION - PENALTY:
All violations of this chapter are civil law violations and are not criminal.
Any person found by the court, after trial, to be in violation of any section
of this chapter shall be subject to punishment by a fine only. For violations
of subsection
6-8-2(A) of this chapter the fine shall be a minimum fine of one hundred
dollars ($100.00) and a maximum fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00). For
violations of subsection
6-8-2(B) of this chapter the fine shall be a minimum fine of one hundred
dollars ($100.00) and a maximum fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00). (Ord.
2016-4, 11-8-2016)
TITLE 7
HEALTH AND SANITATION
Sanitation; Health   1
Nuisances   2
Garbage And Refuse   3
Reserved   4
Dwelling Unit Standards   5
CHAPTER 1
SANITATION; HEALTH
SECTION:
7-1-1: Sanitary Inspection
7-1-2: Offensive Establishments
7-1-3: Secondhand Goods
7-1-4: Slops And Garbage
7-1-5: Diseased Animals
7-1-6: Smoke
7-1-1: SANITARY INSPECTION:
Whenever it shall come to the knowledge of the Board of Health that the
condition of any building or premises is injurious to the health or dangerous
to the lives of the occupants or of the public, the Health Officer shall make a
thorough examination of the building or premises, and upon his report, the
Board of Health shall direct and instruct as to the remedy of such condition;
and if this is not remedied within a reasonable time, the Board of Health shall
cause such building or premises to be put in good sanitary order at the cost of
the individual responsible for, or causing such unhealthy or dangerous
condition. (Ord. 18, 9-2-1908; amd. 1979 Code)
7-1-2: OFFENSIVE ESTABLISHMENTS:
No slaughterhouse, stockyard, cattle yard or shed, feed yard, fertilizing
works, soap factory, dye works, starch factory, rendering plant or any other
business causing noxious odors or whose operation may be detrimental to public
health shall be established or maintained within the jurisdiction of the Board
of Health, except under license granted by special ordinance of the City
Council. (Ord. 18, 9-2-1908; amd. 1979 Code)
7-1-3: SECONDHAND GOODS:
It shall be unlawful to sell, expose or offer for sale any article of
secondhand clothing, wearing apparel or other article by means of which disease
may be conveyed, unless the same has first been thoroughly disinfected under
the directions of the Health Officer. (Ord. 18, 9-2-1908; amd. 1979 Code)
7-1-4: SLOPS AND GARBAGE:
It shall be unlawful to throw, discharge or deposit in any place within the
jurisdiction of the Board of Health, any garbage, meats, slops, animal matter,
suds, vegetables, filth, night soil, stable drippings or dead animals or offal
of any kind, except in such places as may be designated as dumping grounds by
the Board of Health. (Ord. 18, 9-2-1908; amd. 1979 Code)
7-1-5: DISEASED ANIMALS:
No domestic animal afflicted with disease shall run at large or be exposed in
any public place, whereby the health of man or beast may be affected, within
the limits of the City, nor shall such diseased animal be shipped or removed
from the premises of its owner, except under the supervision of the Health
Officer of the City, or of the State veterinarian. It is hereby made the duty
of the Board of Health to secure such disposition of any diseased animal, and
such treatment of infected premises, as to prevent the communication and spread
of the contagion or infection, except in cases where the State veterinarian is
empowered to act; and in all such cases, the Board of Health shall cooperate
with the State veterinarian so far as such cooperation may be necessary to the
protection of the health of the citizens of the City. (Ord. 18, 9-2-1908; amd.
1979 Code)
7-1-6: SMOKE:
It shall be unlawful for the owners, lessees, tenants or managers of every
blacksmith or other shop, forge, foundry, manufactory or other business to
allow smoke, dust, gas or offensive odor to escape from any such building,
place or premises, to the detriment or annoyance of others. (Ord. 18, 9-2-1908;
amd. 1979 Code)
CHAPTER 2
NUISANCES
SECTION:
7-2-1: In General
7-2-1-1: Nuisances Declared Unlawful
7-2-1-2: Nuisance Defined, Generally
7-2-1-3: Nuisances Not Enumerated Herein
7-2-1-4: Enumeration Not Exclusive
7-2-1-5: Duty Of Officers To Investigate; Power Of Entry
7-2-1-6: Notice To Proper Officials
7-2-2: Certain Nuisances Declared
7-2-2-1: Foul Odors, Filth
7-2-2-2: Rubbish, Dry Grass
7-2-2-3: Weeds
7-2-2-4: Petroleum Products, Explosives
7-2-2-5: Unsafe Buildings
7-2-2-6: Abandoned Refrigerators
7-2-2-7: Inoperable Motor Vehicles, Equipment
7-2-2-8: Dust, Cinders
7-2-2-9: Scaffolding, Ladders
7-2-2-10: Storage Of Personalty As Nuisance
7-2-2-11: Disorderly Crowd Or Assembly
7-2-3: Abatement
7-2-3-1: Notice To Abate Nuisance
7-2-3-2: Abatement Of Nuisance; City To Abate; Time Limits
7-2-3-3: Failure To Abate, Separate And Recurring Offense
7-2-3-4: Failure To Abate; Abatement By City
7-2-3-5: Summary Abatement By City When Emergency Or On Public Property
7-2-3-6: Cost Of Abatement; Debt Of Owner
7-2-1: IN GENERAL:
7-2-1-1: NUISANCES DECLARED UNLAWFUL:
It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any person to wilfully
or negligently create, erect, maintain or permit a nuisance to exist anywhere
within the City. (1979 Code)
7-2-1-2: NUISANCE DEFINED, GENERALLY:
Any thing, act, omission, occupation or condition which shall exist or continue
for such length of time as to:
   (A)   Substantially annoy, injure or endanger the health, safety, peace or
welfare of the public; or
   (B)   In any way render the public insecure in life or property; or
   (C)   Greatly offend the public morals or decency; or
   (D)   Unlawfully and substantially interfere with, obstruct or render
dangerous for passage any street, sidewalk, alley, navigable body or other
public way or place,
is hereby declared a nuisance. (1979 Code)
7-2-1-3: NUISANCES NOT ENUMERATED HEREIN:
Any nuisance declared by statute, this chapter or other provisions of this Code
or ordinances of the City shall be enforceable under the provisions of this
chapter as if enumerated specifically herein. (1979 Code)
7-2-1-4: ENUMERATION NOT EXCLUSIVE:
Nuisances enumerated in this chapter shall not be deemed exclusive, but are in
addition to and to be construed in conjunction with any other nuisances
enumerated in statutes or other provisions of this Code or ordinances of the
City. (1979 Code)
7-2-1-5: DUTY OF OFFICERS TO INVESTIGATE; POWER OF ENTRY:
For the purpose of discovering nuisances it shall be the duty of the Police,
Fire, Health and Codes Enforcement Officer to investigate, confirm, report any
nuisances coming to their attention. (1979 Code)
7-2-1-6: NOTICE TO PROPER OFFICIALS:
Whenever any nuisance shall be reported to or investigated and determined by
the Police, Fire, Health or Codes Enforcement Officer, notice shall be given to
the owner or person in control of the property or premises involved, and to the
appropriate City officials whose functions include the abatement of such
nuisances. (1979 Code)
7-2-2: CERTAIN NUISANCES DECLARED:
7-2-2-1: FOUL ODORS, FILTH:
It is hereby declared to be a nuisance and a danger to the health, safety,
welfare, peace and comfort of the City and its residents for any person:
   (A)   Businesses: To conduct any business or to use any premises so as to
create an offensive or foul odor which taints the air and renders it nauseous
to persons in the vicinity; or (1979 Code)
   (B)   Vegetable Matter: To cause or permit to be collected or to remain upon
any premises or place any slop or other vegetable matter of any kind which is,
or is likely to become, putrid, foul or offensive; or
   (C)   Cellars, Vaults, Privies: To cause or permit any cellar, vault,
cistern, drain, privy, yard or other premises whatsoever to become, from any
cause, foul or offensive or injurious to the public health; or
   (D)   Stagnant Water: To permit to be collected or to stand upon any
premises any foul or stagnant water of any kind; or
   (E)   Foul Or Noxious Substances: To use, deposit or keep any property,
substance or thing emitting or causing any foul, offensive, noisome, nauseous
or noxious odor, effluvia or stench particularly repulsive to the physical
senses and which annoys, discomforts or endangers the welfare, health or safety
of any person. (1979 Code; amd. Ord. 2015-3, 9-22-2015)
For citations under this section, see section
1-4-1-1 of this Code. (2018 Code)
7-2-2-2: RUBBISH, DRY GRASS:
It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and health, and a nuisance
for any person to cause or permit:
   (A)   Rubbish, Rags: The deposit or accumulation of any refuse, oil rags,
rubbish or other materials or substances of any kind, so as to constitute a
fire hazard; or
   (B)   Dry Grass, Vegetation: The deposit, accumulation, existence or growth
upon any property of any dry or dead weeds, grass, vegetation or other like
substances of any kind, so as to constitute a fire hazard. (1979 Code)
7-2-2-3: WEEDS 1 :
It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and health and a nuisance
for any person to cause or permit:
   (A)   Jimson, Burdock: Any weeds, such as jimson, burdock, ragweed, thistle,
cockleburs, or other weeds of a like kind, to grow in any lot or tract of land
in the City. (1979 Code)
   (B)   Height: Any weeds, grass or plants other than trees, bushes, flowers,
vegetables or other ornamental plants to grow to a height exceeding six inches
(6") anywhere in the City. (1979 Code; amd. Ord. 2006-6, 6-9-2006)
   (C)   Barberry Bushes: Growth of the bush of the tall, common or European
barberry, further known as Berberis vulgaris or its horticultural varieties,
within the City. (1979 Code)
For citations under this section, see section
1-4-1-1 of this Code. (2018 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See also title 6, chapter 5 of this Code.
7-2-2-4: PETROLEUM PRODUCTS, EXPLOSIVES:
It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and a nuisance for any
person to cause or permit:
   (A)   Petroleum Products: The accumulation or storage, within one hundred
(100) yards of any building occupied as a residence or business, other than a
licensed gasoline service station, of any petroleum, naphtha, benzine, coal
oil, gasoline, kerosene, turpentine or other petroleum products or inflammable
substances of any kind, in quantities greater than fifty (50) gallons except
no. 2 fuel oil or heavier, used for heating purposes; or
   (B)   Explosives: The deposit, accumulation, storage or presence, within one
hundred (100) yards of any building occupied as a residence or business of any
powder magazine, nitroglycerine, dynamite or other explosive substance of any
kind. (1979 Code)
7-2-2-5: UNSAFE BUILDINGS:
It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety, and a nuisance for any
person, to construct or maintain any buildings or structures in violation of
any of the building provisions of this Code, or any building which is in an
unsanitary condition, or in an unsafe or dangerous condition, or which in any
manner endangers the health or safety of any person or persons. Every building
or part thereof which is in an unsanitary condition by reason of the basement
or cellar being damp or wet, or by reason of the floor of such basement or
cellar being covered with stagnant water, or by reason of the presence of sewer
gas, or by reason of any portion of the building being infected with disease or
being unfit for human habitation, or which by reason of any other unsanitary
condition is a source of sickness or which endangers the public health, is
hereby declared to be a public nuisance. (1979 Code)
7-2-2-6: ABANDONED REFRIGERATORS:
It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and a nuisance for any
person to cause or permit the existence or storage in any place accessible to
children of any abandoned or discarded refrigerator, icebox, ice chest, deep
freeze or other airtight appliance or container of any kind, of a capacity of
one and one-half (11/2) cubic feet or more, from which the lids, doors or other
covers have not been removed or which cannot easily be opened by a child, by
means of pushing only, from the inside thereof. (1979 Code)
7-2-2-7: INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLES, EQUIPMENT:
It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and a nuisance for any
person to cause or permit the existence or storage upon any premises within the
City for more than fifteen (15) days of:
   (A)   Any unused, stripped, junked, wrecked or otherwise inoperable motor
vehicle of any kind, or of any other vehicle, implement, machinery, equipment
or other personal property of any kind, which is no longer safely operable or
usable for the purpose for which it was manufactured; or
   (B)   Any parts of such motor vehicle or equipment or old iron, metal,
glass, paper, cordage or other waste or discarded secondhand material which has
been a part, or intended to be a part, of any motor vehicle, the sum of which
parts of material shall be equal in bulk to one or more automobiles, except
within a duly licensed junk yard; provided, however, that this section shall
not be construed to apply to any such motor vehicle or equipment, etc., that is
kept within a building when not in use, or to historical motor vehicles
maintained as such, over twenty five (25) years of age. (1979 Code)
   (C)   For the purposes of this section: "Inoperable motor vehicle" means any
motor vehicle from which the engine, wheels or other parts have been removed,
or on which the engine, wheels or other parts have been altered, damaged or
otherwise so treated as to render the vehicle incapable of being safely driven
under its own motor power, or any motor vehicle not displaying valid registered
plates and/or stickers; provided, however, that this definition shall not be
construed to include any motor vehicle which has been rendered temporarily
incapable of being driven under its own motor power in order to perform
ordinary service or repair operations. (1979 Code; amd. 2018 Code)
7-2-2-8: DUST, CINDERS:
   (A)   It is hereby declared a menace to the public health and a nuisance for
any person to cause or permit any operations that cause or permit any dirt,
sand, gravel, cinders, ashes, earth or other similar materials to be hauled,
moved, rolled, compacted, scraped, dragged or otherwise disturbed so as to
cause or permit dust to be raised, blown or stirred through the operation of
machinery or otherwise to the detriment of any person or property.
   (B)   Every person engaged in hauling of any sand, dirt, cinders, ashes,
earth or other similar materials or substances, or engaged in the moving,
rolling, compacting, scraping, dragging or other disturbance of soil and the
like, shall make adequate provision as often as is required to arrest and
prevent such dust through the use of salts, oil, chemicals and other materials
used and recommended for retarding or eliminating such dust, subject to the
supervision and approval of the City police. (1979 Code)
7-2-2-9: SCAFFOLDING, LADDERS:
It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and a nuisance for any
person:
   (A)   To erect or use, or to cause or permit to be erected or used, any
insecure or unsafe scaffold or ladder whereby the safety of persons working
thereon or passing thereunder may in any way be endangered.
   (B)   To place or leave, or to cause or permit to be placed or left, any
tools or articles on any such scaffold or ladder in such manner that the same
may fall into any street, sidewalk or other public way, whereby the safety of
persons passing thereunder may in any way be endangered. (1979 Code)
7-2-2-10: STORAGE OF PERSONALTY AS NUISANCE:
   (A)   Nuisance Declared: Unsheltered storage of old, unused, machinery and/
or equipment and personal property of any kind which is no longer safely usable
for the purpose for which it was manufactured, which hereinafter are
collectively described as "personalty" for a period of thirty (30) days or more
(except in licensed junk yards) within the corporate limits of the City is
hereby declared to be a nuisance and dangerous to the public safety.
   (B)   Abatement Of Nuisance By Owners: The owner, owners, tenants, lessees
and/or occupants of any lot within the corporate limits of this City upon which
such storage is made, and also the owner, owners and/or lessees of such
personalty involved in such storage (all of which are hereinafter referred to
collectively as "owners"), shall jointly and severally abate such nuisance by
the prompt removal of such personalty into completely enclosed buildings
authorized to be used for such storage purposes, if within the corporate limits
of the City or otherwise to remove it to a location outside such corporate
limits.
   (C)   Penalty For Failure Of Owner To Abate Such Nuisance: If such owners
allow such nuisance to exist or fail to abate such nuisance, they, and each of
them, upon conviction thereof shall be penalized by the imposition of a fine
not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense and a separate
offense shall be deemed committed for each day during or on which such nuisance
is permitted to exist.
   (D)   Abatement By The City: Whenever such owners fail to abate such
nuisance, then the City shall remove the personalty to a location of its
selection, the expenses therefor to be billed to such owners, jointly and
severally, such bill to be recoverable in a suit at law.
When such personalty has been removed and placed in storage by the City, as
provided for herein, such personalty shall be sold by the City after the lapse
of such time as is provided by law. If the proceeds of such sale are
insufficient to pay the cost of abatement, such owners shall be liable to the
City for the balance of the costs, jointly and severally, to be recoverable in
a suit at law. If the proceeds are in excess of costs, the balance shall be
paid to such owners or deposited in the City Treasury for its use. (Ord. 89-9,
12-12-1989)
7-2-2-11: DISORDERLY CROWD OR ASSEMBLY:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to collect, gather or be a member of a disorderly
crowd or assemblage that makes noises, disturbances or sounds in any house or
in any part of the City in such a manner as to disturb the peace of the
neighborhood or those passing on the street.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any owner, occupant or other person in
control of any property to permit a disorderly crowd or assemblage to gather or
remain on any property in his possession or control. The presence of a
disorderly crowd or assemblage on any real estate in the City shall be prima
facie evidence that the owner or occupant of the property knew of, and
permitted a disorderly crowd or assemblage to gather on such property. (Ord.
93-15, 2-8-1994)
7-2-3: ABATEMENT:
7-2-3-1: NOTICE TO ABATE NUISANCE:
   (A)   Whenever any health or building official or inspector, or any police
or fire officer, determines that a nuisance exists on any private property or
premises, except as otherwise provided herein, the proper City official shall
cause a written notice to be served personally upon the owner or, if the owner
cannot be found, upon the occupant or person in control of the property or
premises who is causing, permitting or maintaining such nuisance, and shall
cause a copy of said notice to be conspicuously posted within or upon such
property or premises.
   (B)   Such notice shall fairly appraise such person of the nature of the
nuisance, his duty to abate or remove the nuisance within the time provided
therein, the penalty for failure to abate the same, and shall state that, if
said nuisance is abated by the City, liability for necessary expenses so
incurred shall accrue as provided for in section
7-2-3-6 of this section
7-2-3. (1979 Code)
7-2-3-2: ABATEMENT OF NUISANCE; CITY TO ABATE; TIME LIMITS:
It is hereby declared the duty of any person determined to have created,
