CHAPTER 1
GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
9-1-0: Illinois Vehicle Code Adopted
9-1-1: Definitions
9-1-2: Classification Of Vehicles
9-1-3: Obedience To Police
9-1-4: Scene Of Fire
9-1-5: Signs And Signals
9-1-6: Light Signals
9-1-7: Unauthorized Signs; Interference With Signs
9-1-8: Animals Or Bicycles
9-1-9: Exemptions
9-1-10: Lug Wheels Prohibited
9-1-11: Load Limitation
9-1-12: Toy Vehicles
9-1-13: Left Turns, Certain Intersections
9-1-0: ILLINOIS VEHICLE CODE ADOPTED:
The Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5 as passed, approved
and amended is hereby adopted by the City of Carthage as if fully set out
herein; the provisions therefore be controlling within the corporate limits of
the City of Carthage. (2018 Code)
9-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever in this title the following terms are used, they shall have the
meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section:
   ALLEY: A highway of less than twenty four feet (24') total width used
primarily for delivery service.
   CROSSWALK: That portion of the roadway included within the prolongation of
the sidewalk lines at street intersections.
   DRIVER: Any person who is in actual physical control of a vehicle.
   EMERGENCY VEHICLE: Vehicles of the Police or Fire Department; ambulances;
any vehicle conveying a City official or employee in response to an emergency
official call.
   EXPLOSIVE: Any chemical compound or mechanical mixture that is commonly used
or intended for the purpose of producing an explosion and which contains any
oxidizing and combustive units or other ingredients in such proportions,
quantities or packing that an ignition by fire, by friction, by concussion, by
percussion, or by detonator of any part of the compound or mixture may cause
such a sudden generation of highly heated gases that the resultant gaseous
pressures are capable of producing destructible effects on contiguous objects
or of destroying life or limb.
   FARM TRACTOR: Every motor vehicle designed and used primarily as a farm
implement for drawing plows, mowing machines and other implements of husbandry.
   FLAMMABLE LIQUID: Any liquid which has a flash point of seventy degrees
Fahrenheit (70°F) or less, as determined by a tagliabue or equivalent closed
cup test device.
   IMPROVED HIGHWAY: A roadway of concrete, brick, asphalt, macadam or gravel.
   INTERSECTION: The area embraced within the prolongation of the property
lines of two (2) or more streets which join at an angle, whether or not such
streets cross.
   LANED HIGHWAY: A street, the roadway of which is divided into three (3) or
more clearly marked lanes for vehicular traffic.
   LOADING ZONE: The space adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of
vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers or materials.
   METAL TIRE: Every tire the surface of which in contact with the roadway is
wholly or partly of metal or other hard, nonresilient material.
   MOTOR VEHICLE: Every vehicle which is self-propelled.
   MOTORCYCLE: Every motor vehicle having a saddle for the use of the rider and
designed to travel on not more than three (3) wheels in contact with the
ground, but excluding a tractor.
   PARK: To stand a vehicle, whether occupied or not, for a period of time
greater than is reasonably necessary for the actual loading or unloading of
persons.
   PEDESTRIAN: Any person afoot.
   PNEUMATIC TIRE: Every tire in which compressed air is designed to support
the load.
   PROPERTY LINE: The line marking the boundary between any street and the lots
or property abutting thereon.
   PUBLIC BUILDING: A building used by the City or by any park district, school
district, the State of Illinois or the United States government.
   RESIDENCE DISTRICT: The closely built up residence portion of the City.
   ROAD TRACTOR: Every motor vehicle designed and used for drawing other
vehicles and not so constructed as to carry any load thereon either
independently or any part of the weight of a vehicle or load so drawn.
   ROADWAY: That portion of a street designed or ordinarily used for vehicular
traffic.
   SAFETY ZONE: That portion of a roadway reserved for the exclusive use of
pedestrians, suitably marked or elevated.
   SCHOOL BUS: Every motor vehicle owned by a public or governmental agency and
operated for the transportation of children to or from school or privately
owned and operated for compensation for the transportation of children to or
from school.
   SEMI-TRAILER: Every vehicle without motive power designed for carrying
persons or property and for being drawn by a motor vehicle and so constructed
that some part of its weight and that of its load rests upon or is carried by
another vehicle.
   SIDEWALK: That portion of a street between the curb line or roadway and the
adjacent property line designated for pedestrian use.
   SOLID TIRE: Every tire of rubber or other resilient material which does not
depend upon compressed air for the support of the load.
   STREET: Every way set aside for public travel except foot paths.
   SUBURBAN DISTRICT: That portion of the City other than the closely built up
business and residence districts.
   TRAFFIC: Vehicles, pedestrians and draft or herded animals using any street
for travel.
   TRAILER: Every vehicle without motive power designed for carrying passengers
or property and for being drawn by a motor vehicle and so constructed that no
part of its weight rests upon the towing vehicle.
   TRUCK TRACTOR: Every motor vehicle designed and used primarily for drawing
other vehicles and not so constructed as to carry a load other than a part of
the weight of the vehicle and load so drawn.
   VEHICLE: Every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may
be transported or drawn upon a highway, including bicycles but not including
perambulators or toy vehicles.
   YIELD THE RIGHT-OF-WAY: When required an official sign means the act of
granting the privilege of the immediate use of the intersecting roadway to
traffic within their intersection and to vehicles approaching from the right or
left, but when the highway is clear may proceed into the intersection. (Ord.
587, 3-7-1955; amd. Ord. 69-22, 3-2-1970)
9-1-2: CLASSIFICATION OF VEHICLES:
For the purposes of this title, motor vehicles shall be divided into the
following divisions: first, vehicles which are designed for the carrying of not
more than seven (7) passengers; second, those vehicles which are designed and
used for pulling or carrying freight and also vehicles designed and used for
carrying more than seven (7) persons. (Ord. 587, 3-7-1955)
9-1-3: OBEDIENCE TO POLICE:
Members of the Police Department are hereby authorized to direct all traffic in
accordance with the provisions of this title, or in emergencies as public
safety or convenience may require, and it shall be unlawful for any person to
fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order, signal or direction of a
policeman, except in case of emergency. (Ord. 587, 3-7-1955)
9-1-4: SCENE OF FIRE:
The Fire Department officer in command, or any fireman designated by him may
exercise the powers and authority of a policeman in directing traffic at the
scene of any fire or where the Fire Department has responded to any emergency
call for so long as the Fire Department equipment is on the scene, in the
absence of or in assisting the police. (Ord. 587, 3-7-1955)
9-1-5: SIGNS AND SIGNALS:
It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to disobey the instructions
of any traffic sign or signal placed in view by authority of the City Council
or in accordance with the laws of the State of Illinois. All signs established
by direction of the Governing Body shall conform to the State standards for
traffic signs. (Ord. 587, 3-7-1955)
9-1-6: LIGHT SIGNALS:
Whenever traffic at an intersection is regulated by the type of signal commonly
known as a stop and go signal, the following colors shall indicate the
following commands:
   (A)   Red requires that traffic faced by this color shall stop and remain
standing.
   (B)   Green requires that traffic faced by this color shall move and
continue in motion, except when stopped for the purposes of avoiding an
accident or when stopped at the command of a policeman.
   (C)   Amber or yellow indicates preparation for a change in direction of
traffic movement.
   (D)   When a red lens is illuminated by rapid intermittent flashes, drivers
of vehicles shall stop before entering the intersection.
   (E)   When a yellow lens is illuminated with rapid intermittent flashes,
drivers of vehicles may proceed into the intersection only with extra caution.
(Ord. 587, 3-7-1955)
9-1-7: UNAUTHORIZED SIGNS; INTERFERENCE WITH SIGNS:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to place, maintain or display any
device, other than an official warning or direction sign or signal authorized
by statute or ordinance upon or in view of any street, if such device purports
to be, or is in imitation of, an official warning or direction sign or signal,
or directs or purports to direct the movement of traffic. Any such unauthorized
device is hereby declared to be a nuisance, and may be removed by any
policeman.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to deface, injure, move or
interfere with any official traffic sign or signal. (Ord. 587, 3-7-1955)
9-1-8: ANIMALS OR BICYCLES:
Every person riding a bicycle or an animal, or driving any animal drawing a
vehicle upon any street shall be subject to the provisions of this title
applicable to the driver of a vehicle, except those provisions which can have
no application to one riding a bicycle or driving or riding an animal; provided
that, except in business districts, bicycles may be ridden on sidewalks. (Ord.
587, 3-7-1955)
9-1-9: EXEMPTIONS:
The provisions of this title regulating the movement or parking of vehicles
shall not apply to emergency vehicles while the driver thereof is engaged in
the performance of emergency duties, nor shall such provisions apply to persons
actually engaged in repairing or otherwise improving the streets under
authority of the City Council or of the State of Illinois. (Ord. 587, 3-7-1955)
9-1-10: LUG WHEELS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful within the limits of the City for any person to operate or
drive upon any of the public streets of the City any engine, tractor,
caterpillar, truck or other similar vehicles, having metallic covered wheels,
while such metallic covered wheels have attached or fixed thereto any metallic
cleats or lugs or other similar metallic contrivances, in such manner as to
come in contact with the surface of such street. This provision shall not apply
to the operation on any street of such engine, tractor, caterpillar, truck or
other similar vehicle used in the grading or ditching of such street. (Ord.
395, 3-3-1930)
9-1-11: LOAD LIMITATION:
A vehicular weight limit of four (4) tons be and the same is hereby imposed
upon Main Street, Carthage, Illinois, between Marion Street and Prairie Avenue.
(Ord. 78-6, 7-25-1978; amd. 2018 Code)
The Police Department shall have the discretionary enforcement powers to permit
vehicles in excess of the above limitation to enter upon Main Street while
performing domestic services including, but not limited to, such activities as
garbage collection, moving vans, delivery of goods and merchandise to
residential locations along Main Street and other operations of a local nature
when weather conditions are not unfavorable to the use of Main Street. (Ord.
78-6, 7-25-1978)
Any person who violates this section shall upon conviction thereof, be fined
not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00). (Ord. 78-6, 7-25-1978; amd. 2018 Code)
9-1-12: TOY VEHICLES:
Persons upon skates, rollerblades, skateboards or other toy vehicles may
operate said toy vehicles on the roadway during daylight hours only, provided
there is no obstruction of traffic. No person shall operate any toy vehicle
upon the streets around the public square or on Highway 136 or Highway 94.
Electric motorized scooters may be ridden by persons ten (10) years of age or
older, provided there is no obstruction of traffic. Such scooters must be of
electric battery power only. No gas powered scooters allowed. No person shall
operate said scooters upon the streets around the public square or on Highway
136 or Highway 94. (Ord. 2005-15, 4-12-2005; amd. 2018 Code)
9-1-13: LEFT TURNS, CERTAIN INTERSECTIONS:
No person driving a vehicle shall make a left turn at the following described
intersections:
Intersection of Adams Street and Main Street when approaching the intersection
from the north.
Intersection of Adams Street and Wabash Street when approaching the
intersection from the east.
Intersection of Madison Street and Wabash Street when approaching the
intersection from the south.
Intersection of Main Street and Madison Street when approaching the
intersection from the west. (Ord. 629, 6-24-1957; amd. 2018 Code)
CHAPTER 2
THROUGH, ONE-WAY STREETS; STOP INTERSECTIONS
SECTION:
9-2-1: Through Streets
9-2-2: Right-Of-Way; Stop Streets
9-2-3: One-Way Streets
9-2-4: One-Way Alleys
9-2-5: Yield Right-Of-Way
9-2-1: THROUGH STREETS:
The following streets and parts of streets are hereby declared to constitute
through streets and every driver of a vehicle shall stop before entering the
intersection of any through street:
Adams Street, from Miller Street to Buchanan Street; from Buchanan Street to
the public square; and from the southerly terminus of said street to the public
square.
Buchanan Street, from the City limits to Madison Street.
Douglas Street, from the City limits to Buchanan Street.
Kiwanis Street, from the intersection of Fayette Street to bsi Route 94.
Locust Street, from First Street to Washington Street and from Quincy Road to
Adams Street.
Madison Street, from the north limits of the City to Buchanan Street; from
Buchanan Street to the public square; and from the southerly terminus of said
street to the public square.
Main Street, from the City limits to the public square.
Marion Street, from the north limits of the City to Buchanan Street, from
Buchanan Street to Main Street and from the south limits of the City to Wabash
Street.
Miller Street, from Scofield Street to Madison Street and from Fayette Street
to Madison Street.
Quincy Road, from the City limits to Locust Street.
Scofield Street, from the north limits of the City to Buchanan Street, from
Buchanan Street to Wabash Street and from the south limits of the City to
Wabash Street.
Wabash Street, from the east limits of the City to the public square, and from
the westerly terminus of said street to the public square.
Walnut Street, from Washington Street to Head Street and from the east limits
of the City to Head Street.
Washington Street, from Miller Street to Buchanan Street, from Buchanan Street
to Main Street and from the southern limits of the City to Wabash Street. (Ord.
69-22, 3-2-1970; amd. Ord. 2007-5, 8-28-2007)
9-2-2: RIGHT-OF-WAY; STOP STREETS:
   (A)   The City may, in its discretion, when traffic conditions warrant such
action give preference to traffic upon any of the streets under its
jurisdiction, or with traffic crossing or entering such street by erecting
proper stop signs or stoplights.
   (B)   The driver of a vehicle shall stop as required by section
9-2-1 of this chapter at the entrance of a through street and shall yield the
right-of-way to other vehicles which have entered the intersection from said
through street or which are approaching so closely on said through street as to
constitute an immediate hazard, but said driver having so yielded may proceed
at such time as a safe interval occurs.
   (C)   The driver of a vehicle shall likewise stop in obedience to a stop
sign as required herein at an intersection where a stop sign is erected at one
or more entrances thereto although not a part of a through street and shall
proceed cautiously, yielding to vehicles not so obliged to stop which are
within the intersection or approaching so closely as to constitute an immediate
hazard, but then may proceed.
   (D)   Where stop signs or flashing red signals are placed at an intersection
or at a plainly marked crosswalk between intersections, drivers of vehicles
shall stop before entering the nearest crosswalk and pedestrians within or
entering the crosswalk at either edge of the roadway shall have the right- of-
way over a vehicle so stopped. Drivers of vehicles having so yielded the right-
of-way to pedestrians entering or within the nearest crosswalk at an
intersection shall also yield the right-of-way to pedestrians within any
crosswalk at the intersection. (Ord. 69-22, 3-2-1970)
9-2-3: ONE-WAY STREETS:
The following streets are hereby designated as one-way streets:
Adams Street, between its intersections with Wabash Street and Main Street.
Madison Street, between its intersections with Main Street and Wabash Street.
Main Street, between its intersections with Adams Street and Madison Street.
Wabash Street, between its intersections with Madison Street and Adams Street.
And every driver of a "vehicle" as defined in section
9-1-1 of this title except "emergency vehicles", as also defined in section
9-1-1 of this title shall proceed in the direction indicated on the following
streets:
Adams Street, between Wabash Street and Main Street drive in a westerly
direction.
Madison Street, between Main Street and Wabash Street drive in a southerly
direction.
Main Street, between Adams Street and Madison Street drive in a westerly
direction.
Wabash Street, between Madison Street and Adams Street drive in an easterly
direction. (Ord. 629, 6-24-1957)
9-2-4: ONE-WAY ALLEYS:
The following alleys are hereby designated as one-way alleys:
   (A)   Each of the alleys connecting with Wabash Street, South Adams Street,
Main Street and South Madison Street on the public square in the City for a
distance of one-half (1/2) block from the streets forming the public square in
the City. No driver of a "vehicle" as defined in section
9-1-1 of this title, except emergency vehicles, shall drive in a direction
leading into the public square of the City in such enumerated alleys. No driver
of a vehicle, except emergency vehicles, shall enter upon the public square of
the City from any alley connecting with the public square of the City.
   (B)   The alley originating at North Madison Street running east to the
alley running north and south between Main Street and Walnut Street, commencing
at North Madison Street and running easterly.
   (C)   The alley originating at North Adams Street running west to the alley
running north and south between Main Street and Walnut Street, commencing at
North Adams Street and running westerly.
   (D)   The alley originating at Main Street between Adams Street and
Washington Street, running south to the alley running east and west between
Main Street and Wabash Street, commencing at Main Street and running southerly.
   (E)   The alley originating at the alley running north and south between
Wabash Street and Cherry Street, commencing at the southeast corner of lot 6 in
block 26 in the original town, now City of Carthage, and running westerly to
Adams Street.
   (F)   The alley originating at Wabash Street running north to the alley
running east and west between South Marion Street and South Madison Street,
commencing at Wabash Street and running northerly.
   (G)   The alley originating at Main Street running north to the alley
running east and west between North Marion Street and North Madison Street,
commencing at Main Street and running northerly.
   (H)   The alley originating at North Madison Street running west to the
alley running north and south between Main Street and Walnut Street, commencing
at North Madison Street and running westerly.
   (I)   The west one-half (1/2) of the alley originating at Lincoln Street
between Buchanan Street and Walnut Street.
   (J)   The alley originating at Buchanan Street running south to Wabash
Street between Adams Street and Washington Street, commencing at Buchanan
Street and running southerly.
No "driver" as defined in section
9-1-1 of this title, except emergency vehicles, shall drive upon the enumerated
alleys other than in the direction so stated in this section. (Ord. 97-10, 10-
14-1997)
9-2-5: YIELD RIGHT-OF-WAY:
The City with reference to streets under its jurisdiction may, when traffic
conditions warrant such action, give preference to traffic through any
intersection as yield right-of-way entrances by erecting yield right-of-way
signs in lieu of stop signs.
   (A)   The driver of any vehicle in obedience to a yield right- of-way sign
shall reduce the speed of his vehicle to not more than twenty (20) miles per
hour and shall yield the right-of- way to other vehicles which have entered the
intersecting street either from the right or left or which are approaching so
closely on said intersecting street as to constitute an immediate hazard; but
said driver having so yielded may proceed at such time as a safe interval
occurs.
   (B)   If a driver is involved in a collision at an intersection or
interferes with the movement of other vehicles after driving past a right-of-
way sign, such collision or interference shall be deemed prima facie evidence
of the driver's failure to yield the right-of-way. (Ord. 69-22, 3-2-1970)
CHAPTER 3
RESERVED
(2018 Code)
CHAPTER 4
PEDESTRIANS
SECTION:
9-4-1: Right-Of-Way
9-4-2: Using Roadway
9-4-3: Signals
9-4-4: Standing On Sidewalk
9-4-5: Prohibited Crossing
9-4-6: Walking Along Roadways
9-4-7: Blind Pedestrians
9-4-1: RIGHT-OF-WAY:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to drive into any
crosswalk without the exercise of due and proper care in view of the special
use made thereof by pedestrians.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful to drive any vehicle into any crosswalk while
there is in such crosswalk upon the half of the roadway upon which such vehicle
is traveling any pedestrian engaged in crossing the roadway until such
pedestrian shall have passed beyond the path of such vehicle, when the
pedestrian shall indicate his intention to cross.
   (C)   The driver of a vehicle shall stop before entering any crosswalk when
any other vehicle proceeding in the same direction is stopped at such crosswalk
for the purpose of permitting a pedestrian to cross. (Ord. 587, 3-7-1955)
9-4-2: USING ROADWAY:
   (A)   At no place shall a pedestrian cross any roadway other than by the
most direct route to the opposite curbing, and when crossing any place other
than a crosswalk he shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the
roadway.
   (B)   No person shall stand or loiter in any roadway other than in a safety
zone, if such act interferes with the lawful movement of traffic.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person to stand in a roadway for the
purpose of soliciting a ride from the driver of any vehicle. (Ord. 587, 3-7-
1955)
9-4-3: SIGNALS:
At intersections where traffic is directed by a policeman or by a stop and go
signal, it shall be unlawful for any pedestrian to cross the roadway other than
the released traffic, if such crossing interferes with the lawful movement of
traffic. (Ord. 587, 3-7-1955)
9-4-4: STANDING ON SIDEWALK:
It shall be unlawful for a pedestrian to stand upon any sidewalk except as near
as is reasonably possible to the building line or curb line, if such standing
interferes with the use of said sidewalk by other pedestrians. (Ord. 587, 3-7-
1955)
9-4-5: PROHIBITED CROSSING:
   (A)   Between adjacent intersections at which traffic-control signals are in
operation, pedestrians shall not cross at any place except in a crosswalk.
   (B)   No pedestrian shall cross a roadway other than in a crosswalk in any
business district.
   (C)   No pedestrian shall cross a roadway other than in a crosswalk upon any
through street. (Ord. 587, 3-7-1955)
9-4-6: WALKING ALONG ROADWAYS:
   (A)   Where sidewalks are provided it shall be unlawful for any pedestrian
to walk along and upon an adjacent roadway.
   (B)   Where sidewalks are not provided any pedestrian walking along and upon
a highway shall when practicable walk only on the left side of the roadway or
its shoulder facing traffic which may approach from the opposite direction.
(Ord. 587, 3-7-1955)
9-4-7: BLIND PEDESTRIANS:
Any blind person who is carrying in a raised or extended position a cane or
walking stick which is white in color or white tipped with red, or who is being
guided by a dog, shall have the right- of-way in crossing any street or
highway, whether or not traffic on such street or highway is controlled by
traffic signals, anything in this title to the contrary notwithstanding. The
driver of every vehicle approaching the place where a blind person, so carrying
such a cane or walking stick or being so guided, is crossing a street or
highway shall bring his vehicle to a full stop and before proceeding shall take
such precautions as may be necessary to avoid injury to the blind person. The
provisions of this section shall not apply to a blind person who is not so
carrying such a cane or walking stick or who is not guided by a dog, but the
other provisions of this chapter relating to pedestrians shall then be
applicable to such person. However, the failure of a blind person to so use or
carry such a cane or walking stick or to be guided by a guide dog when walking
on streets, highways or sidewalks shall not be considered evidence of
contributory negligence. (Ord. 587, 3-7-1955)
CHAPTER 5
PARKING RULES
SECTION:
9-5-1: No Parking Places
9-5-2: Parking At Curb
9-5-3: Vehicles for Sale
9-5-4: Loading Zone
9-5-5: All Night Parking
9-5-6: Alleys
9-5-7: Cab Stands, Bus Stands
9-5-8: Parking Limits
9-5-9: Parking Lines, Markings
9-5-1: NO PARKING PLACES:
At any time it shall be unlawful to permit any vehicle to stand in any of the
following places, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or
in compliance with the directions of a policeman or traffic signal:
   (A)   In any intersection;
   (B)   In a crosswalk;
   (C)   Upon any bridge or viaduct, or in any subway or the approach thereto;
   (D)   Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within twenty feet
(20') of a point on the curb immediately opposite the end of a safety zone;
   (E)   Within thirty feet (30') of a traffic signal, stop sign or a through
street sign on the approaching side;
   (F)   Within twenty feet (20') of any intersection;
   (G)   At any place where the standing of a vehicle will reduce the usable
width of the roadway for moving traffic to less than eighteen feet (18');
   (H)   At any curb within fifteen feet (15') of a fire hydrant;
   (I)   At any place where the vehicle would block the use of a driveway;
   (J)   Within fifty feet (50') of the nearest rail of a railroad grade
crossing;
   (K)   Within twenty feet (20') of the driveway entrance to any Fire
Department station and on the side of the street opposite the entrance to any
such station within seventy five feet (75') of such entrance;
   (L)   On any sidewalk or parkway;
   (M)   On the roadway side of any vehicle parked at the edge or curb of a
street; (Ord. 587, 3-7-1955)
   (N)   At any place where official signs prohibit parking or at any place
where the curbing adjacent to the street or roadway has been painted a red or
yellow color; (Ord. 72-22, 1-2-1973; amd. 2018 Code)
   (O)   Beginning at a point on the north side of Buchanan Street a distance
of one hundred six feet (106') east of the east side of the intersection of
West Street and Buchanan Street and thence east along the north side of
Buchanan Street for a distance of six hundred nineteen feet (619'), excepting
therefrom that portion of the north side of Buchanan Street located two hundred
twenty two feet (222') east of the east side of the intersection of West Street
and Buchanan Street for a distance of two hundred twenty eight feet (228')
east; (Ord. 86-5, 7-22-1986)
   (P)   It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on Buchanan Street from the
west corporate limits to the east corporate limits, other than on the north
side of the street from one hundred ten feet (110') west of the center line of
Dallas Street to two hundred sixty five feet (265') west of the center line of
Douglas Street and on the south side of the street from six hundred fifty five
feet (655') east of the center line of West Street to three hundred twenty feet
(320') west of the center line of Douglas Street, and with the right wheels of
the vehicle within twelve inches (12") of the curb and the vehicle facing in
the direction of traffic in the adjacent traffic lane. (Ord. 94-7, 3-28-1995)
Ordinances specifically designating certain streets or parts of streets where
parking is prohibited shall be and remain on file in the Office of the City
Clerk. (1979 Code)
9-5-2: PARKING AT CURB:
   (A)   No vehicle shall be parked with the left side of such vehicle next to
the curb, and it shall be unlawful to stand or park any vehicle in a street
other than parallel with the curb and with the two (2) right wheels of the
vehicle within twelve inches (12") of the regularly established curb line,
except that upon those streets that have been marked for angle parking,
vehicles shall be parked at the angle to the curb indicated by such marks.
(Ord. 587, 3-7-1955)
9-5-3: VEHICLES FOR SALE:
It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle upon any street for the purpose of
displaying it for sale, or to park any vehicle upon any business street from
which vehicle merchandise is peddled. (Ord. 587, 3-7-1955)
9-5-4: LOADING ZONE:
During the times specified herein it shall be unlawful for the driver of a
vehicle to stand a passenger vehicle for a period of time longer than is
necessary for the loading or unloading of passengers, not to exceed three (3)
minutes, and for the driver to stand any freight carrying vehicle for a period
of time longer than is necessary to load, unload and deliver materials, not to
exceed thirty (30) minutes, in any of the following places:
   (A)   In any public alley, during any hour of the day or night.
   (B)   At any place not to exceed seventy five feet (75') along the curb
before the entrance to any hospital or hotel at any time.
   (C)   At any place not to exceed seventy five feet (75') along the curb
before the entrance to a public building between eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and
six o'clock (6:00) P.M., except on Sunday.
   (D)   Directly in front of the entrance to any theater at any time the
theater is open for business. (Ord. 587, 3-7-1955)
9-5-5: ALL NIGHT PARKING:
No person shall park a vehicle on any street for a period of time longer than
thirty (30) minutes between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and five
o'clock (5:00) A.M. of any day, except physicians on emergency calls or where
posted. (Ord. 587, 3-7-1955; amd. 2018 Code)
9-5-6: ALLEYS:
No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner or under such
conditions as to prevent the free movement of vehicular traffic, and no person
shall stop, stand or park a vehicle within an alley in such position as to
block the driveway entrance to any abutting property. (Ord. 587, 3-7-1955)
9-5-7: CAB STANDS, BUS STANDS:
No vehicle other than a licensed taxicab shall be parked in any area designated
by authority of the City Council as a cab stand; and no vehicle other than a
bus shall be parked in a place so designated as a bus loading zone. (Ord. 587,
3-7-1955)
9-5-8: PARKING LIMITS:
A parking limit of ninety (90) minutes is hereby imposed in the areas
hereinafter designated between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and five
o'clock (5:00) P.M. Monday through Friday, inclusive, of each week and between
the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. on Saturday
of each week:
On the south side of Wabash Street between its intersections with Madison
Street and Adams Street.
On the east side of Adams Street between its intersections with Wabash Street
and Main Street.
On the north side of Main Street between its intersections with Adams Street
and Madison Street.
On the west side of Madison Street between its intersections with Main Street
and Wabash Street.
Every driver of a vehicle as defined in section
9-1-1 of this title, except emergency vehicles, as defined in said section,
shall adhere to the parking lines or markings as are established for vehicles.
It shall be unlawful to permit any vehicle to stand, or to park any vehicle in
any of the areas designated in this section for a period of longer than ninety
(90) minutes on the days and during the hours specified in this section. (Ord.
637, 10-22-1957)
It shall be unlawful to permit any vehicle exceeding the weight of eight
thousand (8,000) pounds to be parked on any street of the City for a period of
time longer than is necessary for the loading or unloading of passengers and
the loading, unloading or delivering of materials. In no event shall the
parking of the vehicles described herein exceed a limit of forty five (45)
minutes. (Ord. 87-9, 1-12-1988)
9-5-9: PARKING LINES, MARKINGS:
It shall be unlawful to permit any vehicle to stand, or to park any vehicle
across or upon any lines or markings established for the regulation of parking
or in any manner so that the vehicle shall not be entirely within the area so
designated by such lines or markings as established for parking at any place
within the City. (Ord. 637, 10-22-1957)
CHAPTER 6
CONDITION OF VEHICLES
SECTION:
9-6-1: Vehicle Lights; Volunteer Firemen
9-6-2: Trucks Prohibited On Certain Streets
9-6-3: Engine Brake Noise
9-6-1: VEHICLE LIGHTS; VOLUNTEER FIREMEN:
Any motor vehicle owned or usually operated by a volunteer fireman may be
equipped with not to exceed two (2) lamps which shall emit a blue light without
glare. One such lamp may be mounted on the front and one may be mounted on the
rear of any such vehicle; except that a flashing blue light may be used only
when such fireman is responding to a fire call. (Ord. 587, 3-7-1955)
9-6-2: TRUCKS PROHIBITED ON CERTAIN STREETS:
It shall be unlawful to drive any truck, except for the purpose of making a
delivery, and then for only one block on any street where official signs
prohibit the driving of such vehicles. (Ord. 587, 3-7-1955)
9-6-3: ENGINE BRAKE NOISE:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to use or operate
within the City of Carthage any mechanical exhaust device, engine brake,
compression brake, or similar device that results in excessive, loud or unusual
noise from such vehicle.
   (B)   Evidence that the noise from the operation of such device is audible
at a distance of three hundred feet (300') from the motor vehicle is prima
facie evidence of a violation. (Ord. 2004-11, 10-26-2004)
   (C)   Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any provisions of
this section shall be subject to punishment by a fine of not less than seventy
five dollars ($75.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each
offense. (Ord. 2004-11, 10-26-2004; amd. 2018 Code)
CHAPTER 7
DRIVERS
SECTION:
9-7-1: Age Limit
9-7-2: Liquor Or Drugs
9-7-3: Accidents
9-7-1: AGE LIMIT:
It shall be unlawful for any person under sixteen (16) years of age to operate
any motor vehicle upon any street in the City, except as otherwise provided by
State law. (Ord. 587, 3-7-1955)
9-7-2: LIQUOR OR DRUGS:
It shall be unlawful for the habitual user of narcotic drugs to operate any
motor vehicle on any street; and it shall be unlawful for any intoxicated
person, or any person under the influence of alcohol or of a narcotic drug, to
operate or attempt to operate any motor vehicle on any street. (Ord. 587, 3-7-
1955)
9-7-3: ACCIDENTS:
The driver of a vehicle which has collided with, or been in an accident with,
any vehicle, person or property in such a manner as to cause injury or damage
shall stop immediately, and render such assistance as may be possible, and give
his true name and residence to the injured person or any other persons
requesting the same on behalf of the injured person, or the owner of the
property damaged, and to a policeman if one is present. A report of each such
accident shall be given by the driver of each vehicle concerned in it to the
Chief of Police within twenty four (24) hours after the accident. (Ord. 587, 3-
7-1955)
CHAPTER 8
SNOWMOBILES
SECTION:
9-8-1: Definitions
9-8-2: Registration
9-8-3: Equipment Required
9-8-4: Regulations
9-8-5: Unattended Vehicles
9-8-6: Traffic Regulations
9-8-7: Penalty
9-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever in this chapter the following terms are used, they shall have the
meaning respectively ascribed to them in this section:
   COWLING: The forward positions of a snowmobile surrounding the motor and
clutch assembly.
   OPERATE: To control the operation of the snowmobile.
   OPERATOR: A person who operates or is in actual control of the snowmobile.
   SNOWMOBILE: A self-propelled vehicle designed for travel on snow or ice in a
natural terrain steered by wheels, skis or runners. (Ord. 80-19, 11-12-1980)
9-8-2: REGISTRATION:
All snowmobiles must be registered with the Department of Conservation and the
numbers shall be properly displayed on each side of the cowling. (Ord. 80-19,
11-12-1980)
9-8-3: EQUIPMENT REQUIRED:
All snowmobiles operated within the City shall have the following equipment:
   (A)   Mufflers which are properly attached and which will reduce the noise
of operation of the vehicle to the minimum noise necessary for operating the
vehicle and no person shall use a muffler cutout, bypass or similar device on
such vehicle.
   (B)   Adequate brakes in good working condition and at least one headlight
and one taillight.
   (C)   A safety or so-called "dead man" throttle in operating condition; a
safety or "dead man" throttle is defined as a device which when pressure is
removed from the accelerator or throttle causes the motor to be disengaged from
the driving track. (Ord. 80-19, 11-12-1980)
9-8-4: REGULATIONS:
The following regulations shall govern the operation of snowmobiles within the
City:
   (A)   All snowmobiles while being operated within the City shall have the
headlight and taillights lighted.
   (B)   The streets of the City may be utilized only for the purposes of
entering and leaving the City and for visitation within. When utilizing the
streets of the City, it may be operated on the pavement as close as possible to
the right side of the road.
   (C)   Snowmobiles may not be operated upon the following streets in the
City: North Madison and South Madison Street; the full length of Buchanan (U.S.
Route 136); on the streets surrounding the courthouse square; Adams Street
between Buchanan Street and Memorial Hospital; Washington Street between
Buchanan Street and Augusta Road; and Illinois Route 94 from Buchanan Street
south.
   (D)   All operators must have in their possession a valid driver's license.
Youthful operators between the ages of twelve (12) and sixteen (16) years who
have been certified by the Department of Conservation may operate a snowmobile
only if accompanied on the snowmobile by a person with a valid driver's
license. (Ord. 80-19, 11-12-1980)
9-8-5: UNATTENDED VEHICLES:
It is unlawful for the owner or operator to leave or allow a snowmobile to be
or remain unattended on public property while the motor is running or with the
keys for starting the vehicle left in the ignition. (Ord. 80-19, 11-12-1980)
9-8-6: TRAFFIC REGULATIONS:
Each person operating a snowmobile shall strictly observe all traffic signs and
signals and all other traffic rules and regulations prescribed for motor
vehicle traffic together with all traffic rules applicable thereto and shall
obey the orders and directions of any police officer of the City authorized to
direct or regulate traffic. (Ord. 80-19, 11-12-1980)
9-8-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon
conviction thereof, forfeit and pay to the City not less than seventy five
dollars ($75.00) for each and every offense. (Ord. 80-19, 11-12-1980; amd. 2018
Code)
CHAPTER 9
GOLF CARTS AND UTILITY TERRAIN VEHICLES
SECTION:
9-9-1: Definitions
9-9-2: Vehicle Requirements
9-9-3: Restrictions
9-9-4: Operation On Golf Carts/Recreational Off-Highway Vehicles/UTV
9-9-5: Annual Registration Of Golf Carts/Recreational Off-Highway Vehicle/UTV
9-9-6: Inspection Of Vehicles
9-9-7: Mandatory Insurance
9-9-8: Operation Limited To Licensed Drivers
9-9-9: Other Laws, Regulations, And Ordinances
9-9-10: Recognition Of Other Jurisdiction Registrations
9-9-11: Use Under the Influence
9-9-12: Convictions
9-9-13: Penalty
9-9-14: Waver Of Fee
9-9-15: Prior Ordinances
9-9-16: Invalidity
9-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this Chapter, the following words, terms. and titles shall have the
following meanings:
 
                                  A vehicle specifically designed and
                                  intended for the purpose of transporting
                                  one or more persons and their golf clubs
                                  or maintenance equipment while engaged
GOLF CART:                        in the playing of gold, supervising the
                                  play of golf, or maintaining the
                                  condition of the grounds on a public or
                                  private golf course as defined by 625
                                  ILCS 5/1-129.9 and 11-1426.1(a)(2) of
                                  the Illinois Vehicle Code.
                                  Any motorized off-highway devise
                                  designed to travel primarily off-
                                  highway, sixty-four (64) inches or less
                                  in width, having a manufacturer's dry
                                  weight of two thousand (2,000) pounds or
RECREATIONAL OFF-HIGHWAY VEHICLE/ less traveling on four (4) or more non-
UTILITY TERRAIN VEHICLE (UTV):    highway tires, designed with a non-
                                  straddle seat and a steering wheel for
                                  steering control, except equipment such
                                  as lawnmowers defined by 625 ILCS 5/1-
                                  168.8 and 5/11-14261(a)(4) of the
                                  Illinois Vehicle Code and go carts.
                                  (Ord. 2022-7, 6-28-2022)
 
9-9-2: VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS:
All vehicles allowed to operate on city streets pursuant to this chapter, shall
be equipped with all of the safety systems and equipment as required by the
Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/11-1426.1) including: Brakes, a steering
apparatus, tires, a rearview mirror, red reflectorized warning devises in the
front and rear, a slow moving emblem on the rear of the vehicle as required in
Section 12-709 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/12-709, a headlight
that emits a white light visible from a distance of five hundred (500) feet to
the front, a tail lamp that emits a red light visible from at least one hundred
(100) feet from the rear, brake lights, turn signals, a windshield and any and
all other safety equipment required to be installed and operational on such
vehicles as set forth in said statute. When operated on a street, a low-speed,
vehicle shall have its headlights and tail lamps lighted as required by Section
12-201 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/12-709. (Ord. 2022-7, 6-28-
2022)
9-9-3: RESTRICTIONS:
All terrain vehicles (ATV) as defined in the Illinois Vehicle Code, go-carts
and all other vehicles that do not meet the requirements set forth in this
Ordinance are not authorized on the roadways of the City of Carthage. (Ord.
2022-7, 6-28-2022)
9-9-4: OPERATION OF GOLF CARTS/RECREATIONAL OFF-HIGHWAY VEHICLES/UTV:
Subject to die requirements of Section 11-1426.1 of the Illinois Vehicle Code,
325 ILCS 5/11-1426.1 which are hereby adopted by reference by the City Council
of the City of Carthage, and the provisions of tills Ordinance, drivers
properly licensed to operate motor vehicles on the roadways or the City of
Carthage AND who are eighteen (18) years of age, are allowed to operate golf
carts and/or UTVs under this Chapter on the roadways of the City of Carthage,
having a posted speed limit of thirty-five (35) miles per hour or less.
However, golf carts and/or UTVs are not allowed on the City sidewalks, Illinois
State Route 136 or 94 in the City of Cartilage, with the exception of a golf
cart/UTV may cross State Route 136 or 94 at a 90 degree angle. These vehicles
are also not allowed to operate on the sections of Main, South Madison, Wabash,
and South Adams Streets that are adjacent to the Cartilage Courthouse Square
Historic District. (Ord. 2022-7, 6-28-2022)
9-9-5: ANNUAL REGISTRATION OF GOLF CARTS/ RECREATIONAL OFF-HIGHWAY VEHICLE/UTV:
No vehicle authorized under this Title and Chapter, shall be operated on any
street or alley in the City of Carthage unless the owner(s) thereof shall have
first registered such vehicle with the City of Cartilage in accordance with the
following requirements:
   A.   Registration of such vehicle shall be administered by the Chief of
Police of the City of Carthage, or his designee, an application for
registration may be made on a form prescribed by die City of Carthage. Said
form shall include a statement under oath or penalties of perjury that the
vehicle proposed to be registered meets the definition of the vehicles defined
by the state statute or in Section
9-9-1 of this Chapter and shall be accomplished by an annual registration fee
of one hundred and twenty-five dollars ($125.00) and proof of liability
insurance for said vehicle having at least the same limits of coverage as
required from time to time for motor vehicles under the mandatory insurance law
of the State of Illinois.
   B.   Vehicles registered under this Chapter and Section of the City of
Carthage Municipal Code shall by issued a sticker from the City of Carthage
which shall be affixed to the rear of the vehicle and shall be viewable to a
Police Officer from outside of said vehicle.
   C.   Tire registration of said vehicle shall be effective for a period of
one calendar year and shall be renewed annually on May 1 of each year for one
hundred and twenty-five dollars ($125.00) in die same manner as the original
registration, with the exception that renewals do not require the inspection
that is defined in Section
9-9-6 of this chapter as long as there have not been any violations of this
chapter.
   D.   The registration of said vehicles shall not be transferrable in the
event of a change of ownership. A new registration fee will be required of the
new owner(s). No refund of the original registration fee is allowed in the
event of the change of ownership.
   E.   The registration of said vehicles shall be subject to revocation by the
Chief of Police of the City of Carthage in the event of a violation of the
requirements of Section 11-1426.1 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/11-
1426.1, or any of the provisions of this Ordinance. A revocation of such
registration shall be made in writing and shall set forth the provisions of the
state statute or this Ordinance that has been violated. No refund of the
registration fee is allowed in the event of revocation of said permit
   F.   In the event that the registration of a vehicle is revoked due to a
failure to maintain the required liability insurance or the failure tire
condition of the vehicle in compliance with the state statute of this chapter,
including, but not limited to, maintaining the required safety systems. The
Chief of Police of the City; or his/her designee in his/her discretion may
reinstate the registration upon documentation of reinstatement of the required
insurance coverage or of the repair of modification of the vehicle to cure any
deficiencies, as applicable, if the Chief of Police of the City of Carthage
determines that the violation was not intentional and is not likely to recur.
(Ord. 2022-7, 6-28-2022)
9-9-6: INSPECTION OP VEHICLES:
Vehicles, registered, or proposed to be registered, pursuant to the provisions
of this chapter, shall be subject to inspection before issued said registration
sticker. The inspection, is only required for the first year of registration or
if a sticker lapses by more than thirty days or if there had been a violation
of this chapter or State Law. Vehicle owners may obtain an inspection form from
the City of Carthage Police Department. The City of Cartilage Chief of Police,
or his/her designee, will oversee the scheduling and execution of said
inspections and will be provided completed form by the owner. (Ord. 2022-7, 6-
28-2022)
9-9-7: MANDATORY INSURANCE:
The owner of any vehicle registered under this chapter shah continuously
maintain liability insurance for said vehicle having at least the same limit of
coverage as required from time to time for motor vehicles under the mandatory
insurance law of the State of Illinois. (Ord. 2022-7, 6-28-2022)
9-9-8: OPERATION LIMITED TO LICENSED DRIVERS:
All persons who operate a vehicle under the chapter within the City of Carthage
must have a valid driver's license and be at least eighteen (18) years of age.
(Ord. 2022-7, 6-28-2022)
9-9-9: OTHER LAWS, REGULATIONS, AND ORDINANCES:
Vehicles registered under this chapter shall be operated at all times in
accordance with the provisions of the Illinois Vehicle Code, the rules of the
road contained therein and any other laws, regulations or ordinances governing
the operation of motor vehicles m the City of Carthage as well as the laws,
regulations or ordinances, specifically pertaining to vehicles operated under
this chapter and the operation thereof. (Ord. 2022-7, 6-28-2022)
9-9-10: RECOGNITION OF OTHER JURISDICTION REGISTRATIONS:
The City of Carthage shall recognize registrations from other jurisdictions, so
as long as the registration is current and valid, the vehicle complies with
regulations and requirements of this chapter and the owner and/or operator's
home address is from the municipality where the vehicle is registered. (Ord.
2022-7, 6-28-2022)
9-9-11: USE UNDER THE INFLUENCE:
A person who drives or is in actual physical control of a vehicle authorized
under this chapter on a roadway in the City of Cartilage while under the
influence of alcohol or drugs, is subject to the provisions of Sections 11-500
through 11-502 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/11-500 through 11-502.
Further, a violation of the provisions of tin's Section shall be cause for the
City of Carthage to revoke the permit of the authorized vehicle. (Ord. 2022-7,
6-28-2022)
9-9-12: CONVICTIONS:
Two (2) convictions of any authorized user herein of a vehicle authorized under
the provisions of this chapter, for moving violations concerning such vehicle,
shall cause the registration provided for herein to be revoked for at least one
(1) year. It shall be the City of Carthage Chief of Police to determine if the
registration will be reinstated after the one (1) year revocation. If the Chief
of Police denies reinstatement, the applicant may appeal the decision to the
City Council. The City Council's decision on reinstatement is final. (Ord.
2022-7, 6-28-2022)
9-9-13: PENALTY:
In addition to revocation of tire registration of a vehicle as provided in this
chapter, any person violating any of the provisions of this Chapter shall be
subject to a fifty dollar ($50.00) fine for each offense, court costs and the
City of Cartilage's attorney's fees. The provisions hereof for prosecuting
violations of tins Chapter are not intended in any way to supersede the
provisions of the Illinois Vehicle Code involving the operation of said
vehicles within the City of Cartilage. (Ord. 2022-7, 6-28-2022)
9-9-14: WAVER OF FEE:
The provisions of this Chapter shall apply to the use and operation of a
vehicle solely owned by a unit of local government (i.e. City of Cartilage,
Carthage Park District, etc.); however the registration fee for such vehicles
is waived. (Ord. 2022-7, 6-28-2022)
9-9-15: PRIOR ORDINANCES:
All prior Ordinances and amendments to Ordinances which are inconsistent with
this chapter are hereby repealed. (Ord. 2022-7, 6-28-2022)
9-9-16: INVALIDITY:
If any section, paragraph, sentence, clause, or phrase of this Chapter is
declared or held to be unconstitutional or invalid for any reason, the
remainder or this Chapter shall not be affected thereby and shall remain in
foil force and effect. (Ord. 2022-7, 6-28-2022)
